Author: LINDSAY
Quote: S.tetraptera, Aiton, var. microphylla, Jacq. ... The `Kowhai' of the North Island Maori; the `Kowai' of settlers, - or as the word is variously corrupted and spelt by them, - `Goai' or `Ghoai,' `Goa' or `Ghoa.' According to Hector, the type is known to Otago Maoris as `Houma;' while the term `Kowhai' is applied to var. grandiflora in common with its other varieties. Var. microphylla is also sometimes designated by the colonists the Native `Laburnum' or `Mimosa,' from the similarity of its foliage, in the arboreous condition, to that of these familiar ... European trees.

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: The [kowhai] tree is sometimes called the New Zealand Laburnum. The Maori name is said to mean yellow (the colour of the flowers).

Author: WHITE
Quote: The New Zealand Laburnum ( Sophora tetraptera, (Yellow Kowhai) is a splendid deep yellow, with much larger flowers and calix than the English Laburnum.

Author: FEATON
Quote: On account of the fibrous nature of [ Plagianthus Lyallii' s] inner bark, it is popularly known in the Middle Island as one of the `Ribbon Wood' or `Lace Bark' trees, as is the Hoheria populnea, and its varieties in the Northern Island. Ibid. 55 Hoheria... It is asserted that at one time "Lace-bark" bonnets were quite fashionable in Nelson... HOHERIA POPULNEA ( A.Cunn.) ... The `HOUI' or `WHAU-WHI'.- ... grows abundantly in both Islands... Owing to the chaste [snow-white] appearance of its flowers, it has not inaptly been termed by some the `New Zealand orange Blossom'. The inner bark is peculiar, and consists of layer upon layer of laced fibre, ...From this peculiarity it is called by the settlers the `Thousand Jacket', `lace-bark', or `Ribbon-wood'.

Moving right along,

Properly, to lair up

Lamb: A lamb carcass

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote:
Ages of sheep.
Although there are
many variations, the
following names are
usually used: A
sheep is a lamb
until weaned. After
weaning a lamb is
called a hogget
until shorn. A male
lamb is a ram lamb
until castrated,
then a wether. A
female lamb is a ewe
lamb. After
shearing, a ewe or
ram lamb is usually
called a shorn
hogget until cutting
the first two teeth.
It is then called a
two-tooth. Some use
the term two-tooth
as soon as the lamb
is shorn. Next year
the sheep is a
four-tooth, then a
six-tooth and then
an eight-tooth or
full-mouthed sheep.
It is full-mouthed
as long as the teeth
remain perfect but
then becomes
broken-mouthed and
gummy.

Author: HALL
Quote:
When a lamb peels
off from a mob, it's
called a lamb break.
This is most likely
to occur when
they've become
mismothered - that
is separated from
their mothers in the
mob which, as you
can imagine, makes
them pretty upset.
Lamb breaks are
dreaded by shepherds
because they can
start a chain
reaction, with the
entire mob rapidly
getting out of
control.

Author: ASPINALL
Quote:

Author: Butler, S.
Quote:
He does not wash his
sheep before
shearing, but he

which lamb, but he
'lambs down'
himself.

This 1550ha farm is
located 25km from
Whakatane and
finishes 1200 bulls,
500 other cattle and
lambs down 3000 ewes
(140%) and 900
hoggets.

Most marvellous of
all, it is not his
sheep which lamb,
but he 'lambs down'
himself.

Lamb (l&abreve.m),
v. t. [Prob.
identical with LAM,
v. t., to beat
soundly. See LAM, in
the Dictionary.] To
knock, in a peculiar
figurative sense
(see below); - used
only in the phrase
to lamb down. To
lamb down, (a) To
knock down; - as to
lamb down a check.
See To knock down a
check, under KNOCK.
(b) To entertain (a
person) at a public
house (esp., to
supply him with
liquor) and to
receive a bank check
as payment in
advance, on the
understanding that
the guest's credit
is to cease when the
value of the check
is exhausted; - said
to the keeper of a
public house, esp.
in the Australian
bush. In the second
sense, which is the
usual one, the
phrase commonly
implies extortion
and fraudulent
charges on the part
of the innkeeper.

Author: MORRIS

English verb, of
Scandinavian origin,
and properly spelt
lamm, which means to
thrash, beat.

The all-engrossing

English grasses,
paddocks, bush and
so forth. I was
rather startled to
hear one gentleman
ask another whether
he meant to wash
this year, and
receive the answer
`No.' I soon
discovered that a
person's sheep are
himself. He does not
wash his sheep
before shearing, but
he washes; and, most
marvellous of all,
it is not his sheep
which lamb, but he
`lambs down'
himself.

Author: FORSTER
Quote: Near all the places where the Indians have their huts, there grows a kind of Scurvy-grass or Lepidium , which is an excellent antiscorbutic. Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: BROAD-LEAVED PLANTAIN (Plantago major ), also called ratstail, birdseed, lamb's tongue, and greater plantain, is common on roadsides and trodden places throughout the country and in pastures in the King Country. ... From the middle of the rosette ascends the flower stalk ... , which afterwards give[s] place to seeds, and produce[s] the ratstail appearance that gives the plant one of its trivial names. The long spikes of seed pods are often used for feeding caged birds. ... PLANTAIN (Plantago lanceolata) is commonly called rib grass, lamb's tongue, horse plantain, and soldiers. It is common in pastures and waste places throughout. It forms a rosette of lanceolate leaves about 6 inches long, with prominent or converging veins, giving the name `rib grass'. From the rosette rises the slender flower stalk a foot or more in length, with a crowded mass of tiny brown or black flowers at its tip. These heads are used by children for playing `soldiers,' and so in Scotland the weed is called `Carl Doddie'-that is `Charles and George'- a souvenir of 1745.

Out west, there's
the Nugget Cafe, a
one-shop renaissance
for the former
mining village of
Mangarakau, and
hairy farmer with
ripped lammies and
hearts of gold.

The fame of the West
Coaster's `own'
garment for outdoor
workers - the
ubiquitous miner's
`lammie' - has
spread far afield.
This week a trial
parcel of lammies
was dispatched on
request to members
of the Malayan
Police Force at
Singapore who
indicated in a
letter to the Kumara
firm which has made
a specialty of
supplying lammies
since the gold rush
days that they had
heard of the unique
qualities of the
garment. The full
story of the request
from Singapore is
not known, but it is
believed that
Auckland Chinese
market gardeners may
have been
responsible. For
many years Chinese
gardeners have
adopted the lammie
as almost an
`official uniform'
and supplies for
Auckland are
regularly forwarded
from the small
business in Kumara.
But what is a
lammie? In the first
place it is a
strictly utilitarian
garment with no
claims to
attractiveness in
appearance. The
original type -
still in use after
70 years - was a
loose-fitting almost
shapeless shirt
buttoned in front
and with
elbow-length sleeves
made of flannel and
water-proofed. It is
this proofing
quality which has
established the
popularity of the
lammie. It was an
ideal garment for
outdoor workers in
the West Coast
climate, enabling
them to keep
drywithout the
encumbrance of an
overcoat and it was
soon in general use
on the gold fields,
later to be adopted
by bushworkers,
navvies and many
farmers. At first
the lammie was made
of moleskin, then
grey flannel and
over the past 20
years of navy
flannel, but the
proofing formula has
remained unchanged.
In recent years
there has also been
developed a modified
style, double
breasted Coast
fashion, but the
original shirt style
is still popular.
Apart from the fact
that the historic
gold-mining town of
Kumara is regarded
as the home of the
lammie in New
Zealand, the story
of its origin has
been lost. It is
thought, however,
that it was probably
brought to the
goldfields by the
first Welsh diggers
and that it may have
been spelt `Llamy.'
It was soon almosta
universal garment
among diggers,
including big
contingents of
Chinese miners who
found it ideal both
for utility and for
economy.

[corresp. col.] Sir,
- In reference to
your article on the
West Coast shirt
called a `lammie,'
when a girl over 58
years ago I used to
visit a couple named
Tait who lived in
Dillsmanstown. Mr.
had a sluicing
claim, and a draper
named Todd used to
get special flannel
by the bolt for Mrs.
Tait, and she made
these `lammies.' She
waterproofed them by
dipping them in a
special solution two
or three times and
hanging them on a
line dripping wet,
to dry each time.
They were sold for 2
[pounds] 10/- to 2
[pounds] 15/- but
I'm sure she never
sold one to a
Chinaman. There were
hundreds there
working tailings. It
was Mrs. Tait's own
invention I am sure.
- I am, etc.,

[For Sale Column]
Llamys, double
breasted all sizes
... Hamer's Drapery
Kumara (Phil Duffy,
Prop.)

Author: McDOWALL
Quote: The lamprey (Geotria australis) is eel-like at first glance but closer examination soon reveals that it has no jaws, no paired fins, no bones, and no gill covers (but seven small external gill apertures)... Adult lampreys migrate into freshwater during spring, mostly at night.

Finger ferns (species of Grammitis), hanging spleenwort, sickle spleenwort (Asplenium polyodon), lance fern (Anarthropteris lanceolata) and fork ferns (species of Tmesipteris) are also common on tree-fern trunks or hanging from the branches of forest trees.
The lance fern (Anarthropteris lanceolata) produces new plantlets directly from its roots and on wet rock faces colonies of plants can often been seen linked together in a long string.

now that Crown
pre-emption was
abolished, were free
to sell either to
settlers or to the
Government.

land sellers and the
`land holders'; but
it seems probable
that the great
majority of Maoris,
south of Auckland,
sympathized with the
latter party.

The land hunger is
pretty keen here
(says a Waitara
correspondent of the
Taranaki Herald) ...

Author: WILSON & FRASER
Quote:
There were something
like 110 sections of
an average size,
which works out at
180 acres each, to
offer to those who
suffered from the
prevalent land
hunger.

Author: BROWN
Quote:
But there was a land
hunger [in the
1890s] and forest
clearance could not
await the prior
milling of timber.

Land hunger: the
land fever is now
raging at full
height here: about
every second or
third place is
either sold or for
sale.

Land hunger: There
is a young man in
Hastings who has
applied for sections
of land at nearly
every land ballot
held in the North
Island during the
last two years.

The land hunger is
stretching itself
far and wide ...

Author: WILSON
Quote:
And nearly all the
land-hungry bought
more of these acres
than their capital
warranted; as a
result there were
many failures; but
land-hunger still
increased.

Author: PASCOE
Quote:
He [Colenso] was
needed also to
uphold their cause
against the land
hunger of settlers.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
And though European
greed and land
hunger was
eventually to make a
cruel mockery of the
[Treaty of Waitangi]
document, a certain
amount of its
original spirit
survived and still
survives.
[land-hunger; earth
hunger]

Representatives of
Maori land
incorporations which
have land leased to
the forest service
are understood to be
studying their
options on land that
is to be transferred
... on April 1. ...
But the
incorporations are
now understood to be
reviewing the
changeover and
looking at
newoptions for their
land.

Author: SEWELL
Quote:
All the valuable
spots will be jobbed
away. River banks
will be seized on.
In short all the
Land-jobbing
vultures will be
down upon their
prey.

Author: PORTER
Quote:
The following year J
D Lang's book
appeared in which he
accused the CMS
missionaries of
extensive land
jobbing.
[land-jobbing]

Of late there has
been formed a League
amongst various of
the tribes on Cook's
Straits for
resisting further
alienations of land
to the Europeans ...
The Church of
England missionaries
labour under a
strong suspicion of
fostering and even
originating this
Land League ...
People feel certain
that [Bishop Selwyn]
will do his best to
patch up a hollow
truce and to shield
the murderous
Land-Leaguers.

Author: THOMSON
Quote: To keep this spirit alive, an Anti-landselling League was formed among some of the Taranaki tribes. ... One tribe, not belonging to this League, was induced ... to offer a quantity of land for sale in 1854 ... Ibid. 2/227 SETTLER OPPOSE LAND-LEAGUE [heading]

Land Leagues are the
reasonable protest
of an unrepresented
majority agaist an
aggressive minority.
Notes: G.A. Selwyn Memorandum to Governor Gore Browne

Author: BUDDLE
Quote: About the same time [c1852], and connected with the subject, arose the Taranaki land league. Ibid. 15 The objection ... arose from the foolish idea that is entertained by the Maories that opening roads will certainly lead to the alienation of their lands; as their main object clearly was the formation of a land league to prevent all further sales, ...

Author: GORST
Quote:
If we had educated
the natives in
civilisation ... as
British subjects ...
nothing would have
been heard of
`land-leagues' and
`king-movements'.

Author: MACDONALD
Quote:
The `Maori Land
League' and the
`Maori King
Movement' were
growing into
consistency and
power.

Author: LANCASTER
Quote:
The Taranaki Maoris
were likely to
require some facing
presently, having
established their
own Land League ...

Author: COWAN
Quote:
This growing feeling
culminated in 1852
in the formation of
a confederation of
tribes which came to
be called the Land
League, binding
themselves, so far
as Taranaki was
concerned, to put a
stop to all sales of
land northward of
the Bell Block ...

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
In later years the
settlers came to
believe that a
conspiracy was
hatched against them
at Manawapou; that
the Maoris formed a
`land-league ... a
war league, a league
of blood anddeath'.
In fact, according
to a missionary and
a government land
purchase agent, who
had early news of
the meeting, no
agreement was made.

Author: McNEISH
Quote:
A month before,
Matthew Whitehouse,
the Superintendent,
had told Polson in a
letter that the
natives of the north
were forming land
leagues; in Taranaki
they were arming
themselves and
preparing to drive
the settlers from
their farms.

The term "land
maggots" used by
lifestylers recently
featured in the
Herald may become
part of the language
but possibly not as
a dsecription of
sheep.

Sheep are banned.
"We call them land
maggots," the
Marshalls say.

Author: KING
Quote:
[Hdg] Maori Land
March

Author: KING
Quote:
[After the meal I
[Whina, at a meeting
in1975 at Te Puea
Marae] said, "Why
don'twe march to
Parliament... a
sacred march- for a
sacred purpose, to
hold on to
ourlands?"]

Organisers of the
Maori lands
rightsmarch from
Northland to
Wellington hopeto
complete the more
than 700-mile trekin
about a month.

Mr Ruru denies any
split.. (when
askedabout
statements by the
leader of theland
march, Mrs Whina
Cooper that
thepresent
protesters were a
"disgrace totheir
race."

The distance was
shorter and the
numberswere smaller,
but the sight was no
lessimpressive when
the first Maori
landmarch passed
through Masterton
over 100years ago.
Notes: Check page* I think this refers to the 1863 march, an account of which appeared in the 1863 NZ Advertiser 27 Aug. 2A body of armed natives, mustering 42,passed through Greytown yesterday(Monday). They passed in marching order,appearing to mimic the soldiers. Theywere a very ragged mob, and caused greatlaughter. They were supposed to be goingto a feast at Waianga.A further notice appeared in the 1863 NZ Advertiser 29 Aug. 2It may be true that not more than forty-two armed natives passed through Greytownlast Monday, of whom not more than three-fourths were armed with guns, but was notsuch an exhibition calculated to alarm heisolated settlers, and to prevent themfrom carrying on their usual avocationsin a quiet manner.

Quote:
The fishing nets
will go out at Te
Hapuatonight to feed
the people who
willgather at the
township over the
weekendbefore
setting out on the
700-mile Maoriland
march to Wellington
on Sunday.

Whatever people
might say in
retrospectabout the
1975 Maori land
march whichWhina
Cooper led, it was
still the
mostdramatic gesture
of the Maori
protestseen.

Maori people need to
cooperate more
ifthey are to
consolidate the
gains of theMaori
land march, Dame
Whina Cooper says.

Predictably the
timing and
implicationsof the
great Maori Land
March were
notappreciated by
the Minister of
MaoriAffairs.

[The armed Maoris
that went to
theWaihanga runanga
returned yesterday
inbroken order.
About 30 in number
passedthrough
Carterton, a portion
took thecoast,
Teretahi direction,
and theremainder
proceeded towards
Masterton;their
bearing was civil,
and.. subdued.]

[The armed Maoris
that went to
theWaihanga runanga
returned yesterday
inbroken order.
About 30 in number
passedthrough
Carterton, a portion
took thecoast,
Teretahi direction,
and theremainder
proceeded towards
Masterton;their
bearing was civil,
and.. subdued.]

Matiaha and another
chief.. were
awaitingthe
Superintendent..
their mission
was..to ask the
Superintendent's
permissionfor some
forty armed
Masterton natives
topass through
Greytown. After
theSuperintendent
had with some
hesitationgiven the
permission asked..
Matiaha andhis
friend readily
accepted his
Honor'sinvitation to
lunch.

Thousands of land
marchers
andsympathisers
stood solemnly in
drizzlingrain in
front of Parliament
Buildingsyesterday
as the march leaders
presenteda memorial
of rights asking
Parliament tobring
down comprehensive
legislation forthe
retention of all
Maori land.

[Hdg] Land Marchers
Await Verdict...At
best opinion among
the Maori
landmarchers seems
to be divided on
theresult of the
700-mile long trek
toParliament
Buildings.

Mrs Cooper said the
marchers
hadsacrificed a
great deal in making
themarch.

Author: YATE
Quote:
One of the most
peculiar features in
the character of
this country is the
fern, which
everywhere
flourishes most
luxuriantly
...[note] 57 species
... have been
discovered

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote:
Though there are no
other varieties
which cover so wide
an area, yet the
ferns form such a
prominent feature in
the Flora, that New
Zealand is often
termed `The Land of
Ferns,' and a fern
frond has been taken
as its emblem.

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote:
The land of the
`Maori and Moa,' as
a poet has called
our land, has long
been famous from
both the
ethnological and
zoological
standpoints. ... But
when it comes to the
question of the
plant-life there is
a pause. To be sure,
New Zealand is known
as the land of
ferns, and not
without truth; yet
this admired group
is found nearly all
the world over, and
is really much less
important than are
plenty of the other
indigenous plants.

Author: BATISTICH
Quote:
Sack hut, sack bed,
even your patches
were sack. No wonder
that those who fled
home as soon as they
could spread the
story that New
Zealand was The Land
of Sacks.

Head Word: Land of the Great White Cloud
Quote:
The home of the
Maori in the `Land
of the Great White
Cloud' may, perhaps,
be longcontinued ...

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
Perhaps a week had
passed, 26 men on
the board, mostly
Australians, who
came over in the
off-season making a
good cheque on the
soft cutting New
Zealand flocks, then
hired their
professional ability
back to the land of
the kangaroo, ...

Head Word: Land of the Long Black Cloud
Quote:
Prime Minister Jim
Bolger is refusing
to be dragged into a
row about Australian
election advertising
which paints New
Zealand as "the land
of the long black
cloud".

Head Word: Land of the Long Black Cloud
Quote:
But when the show
moved on to those
Australian Labour
Party "Land of the
Long Black Cloud"
commercials, only
Corkery seemed
concerned about the
democratic right of
New Zealanders to
criticise National
party policies in
front of the
Aussies.

Head Word: Land of the Long Pink Cloud
Quote:
A Christchurch
historian once
described New
Zealand history - as
written - as a view
of a "land of the
long pink cloud".

Head Word: Land of the Long Pink Cloud
Quote:
Neville Phillips,
formerly a professor
and Vice-Chancellor
of Canterbury
University, once
cleverly said that
New Zealand was the
land of "the Long
Pink Cloud."

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cardigan
Quote:
My father made
occasional business
trips for his
pharmaceutical
company to the place
he called "The Land
of the Long White
Cardigan", but I
knew nothing about
the country.

Head Word: land of the long white chord
Quote:
An imaginary
location, a time as
much as a place, the
land of the long
white chord - this
idea of Dunedin is
deeply entrenched.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Quote:
You, too, in the
Land of the Long
White Cloud, will
have a thought for
us ...

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Quote:
... a memento ...
treasured, by
relatives and
friends in `The Land
of the Long White
Cloud'.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Author: HYDE
Quote:
Land was in sight,
just a faint blue
line ..., above it
floating the band of
silver which made
the old Maori
canoe-explorers call
New Zealand
Ao-Te-Aroa - Land of
the Long White
Cloud.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Author: LANCASTER
Quote:
`E-a! My country!
Ao-tea-roa ... [sic]
Land of the Long
White Cloud. The
pakeha god is
stealing from you
all your own old
gods....'

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Quote:
A hundred and fifty
miles were certainly
no hardship to those
[Maori] lads, and at
the finish [of the
service-car journey]
it was the others
who were staring
gaunt ... upon the
land of the long
white cloud.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Author: GOLDBLATT
Quote:
The milk bars, the
rendezvous of the
`Land of the Long
White Cloud', are
interspersed and
barnacled to the
Picture House.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Quote:
land of the Long
White Cloud [transl.
of M AOTEAROA] New
Zealand.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Author: OVENDEN
Quote:
Then it's no trouble
for Intelligence to
... push him off to
anew life, lost in
the land of the long
white cloud.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Author: JACKSON
Quote:
In due course more
men arrived from the
Land of the Long
White Cloud.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Quote: Land of the Long White Cloud with or without the initial capitals) has itself become a familiar variant of the country's name, sometimes appearing as Land of the Great White Shroud, or in shortened form simply as the Long White Cloud. DNZE also records the ironic, punning deflations of this romantic image that have been coined: (Land of) the Long White Shroud (from the 1940s on) and (more recently) Land of the Wrong White Crowds (a 1980s graffito and Land of the Long Black Cloud.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Quote:
In the Land of the
Long White Cloud
thou shalt study the
Dole.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Quote:
Now, 40 years away
from my homeland, I
call it the Land of
the Long White Lie.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Quote:
The cigarette smoke
haze is now
gradually lifting
from the Land of the
Long White Cloud.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Quote:
Something which
makes me feel very
New Zealand is when
I'm overseas and
there's a Maori
concert party
performing songs
about the arrival in
the land of the long
white cloud.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Quote:
Right now the land
of the long white
cloud is broke and
the people are
bitter.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Cloud
Quote:
...the selling of
the country's
natural wonder off
the back of a
fantasy film - land
of the long white
digitally enhanced
cloud, free-market
scenery capital of
the world.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Football
Quote:
What a boring and
lonely business it
must be for this
brightest of foreign
sparks living in the
land of the long
white football, or
should that read the
long brown football?

Head Word: Land of the Long White Shroud
Quote:
New Zealand was
beginning to look
like the Land of the
Long White Shroud
for the Australian
cricket team, ...

Head Word: Land of the Long White Shroud
Quote:
Niu Tireni (Long
White Shroud) / (a
bare-arsed land,
manipulated by the
wrong white crowd of
minority speculators
- with big foreign
investors - busily
weaving a long white
shroud to fit us
all).

Head Word: Land of the Long White Shroud
Quote:
If there are Kiwis
travelling home to
the Land of the Long
White Shroud with
tales of woe and
misery, it's because
they are
unemployable anyway.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Shroud
Author: DAVIN
Quote:
Last I heard of you
was that you had
wangled yourself a
plane back to the
land of the long
white shroud.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Shroud
Quote:
I cannot understand
whinging kiwis who
insist that the long
white shroud still
reigns, this is a
boring or
unsophisticated
place.

Head Word: Land of the Long White Western Tradition
Quote:
...the presence of
Solander on Cook's
first voyage..
suggests that
Swedish was the
second language
spoken in the Land
of the Long White
Western Tradition.

Author: CARR
Quote:
The tussock plains
round Lake Taupo ...
are gardens of Eden
in comparison. No
wonder [the northern
gumfield country] is
christened `The Land
of the Lost'.

Head Word: Land of the Wrong White Crowd
Author: McGILL
Quote:
land of the wrong
white crowd New
Zealand perceived as
dominated by
Pakehas, backlash
c/p variant of
translation of Maori
name for New
Zealand, `Aotearoa',
land of the long
white cloud.

Author: HYDE
Quote:
say `land of three
S's' to any New
Zealander or Aussie
and he'll get you
all right.

I slept in Cass's
bed at the Land
Office, he having
been unable to
return from
Lyttelton.

The Land Office is a
remarkably neat and
I should think
commodious building
... the upper part
used as a Police
Court.

Author: MACKIE
Quote:
Finding that most of
the religious
denominations have
had grants from
government of pieces
of land - ... we
went to the land
office to make some
enquiry on the
subject but being
the day called `Good
Friday', the offices
were closed.

Author: HART
Quote:
At the Land Office
[in Chch in 1852],
which was really the
Government Office,
all the settlers
were congregated ...

The Commissioner's
office is known as
the principal land
office, and in some
of the larger
districts there are
one or more local
offices. It is with
these land offices
the selector has to
transact all
business, ...

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
Some of the Central
runs had been
applied for at the
Dunedin land Office
late in 1857 and
others during 1858.

Author: McNEISH
Quote:
It was only a race
with a missionary to
reach the Land
Office.

Author: ACLAND
Quote:
This completes all
the Class III runs..
except one which I
once saw listed in
an old manuscript
book that used to be
among the Land
Office records.

A man applied at the
Land Office for a
likely piece of
country which he had
seen on his
travels... If no one
else established a
prior claim the
Waste Lands Board
gave him the run

Land Purchase
Commissioners were
appointed.

Author: SELWYN
Vol / Page: Part V (Church in the Colonies XX) 38
Quote:
When ... the events
at the Wairau, and
the Land Question in
general had made a
breach between the
two races; then the
doors began to be
shut in the faces of
the natives, and
language
peculiarlyoffensive
to them was in
common use among the
lower classes: ...

The next step of Sir
George was to place
the `land question'
on a satisfactory
footing, then no
easy job.

Author: BUDDLE
Quote:
Second - The land
Question. To prevent
further alienation
of Native lands is
the great object of
the league, and on
this point the
kingites carry with
them the sympathies
of the majority.

Author: SWAINSON
Quote:
The native land
question remains to
be considered, and
on its satisfactory
solution the
ultimatefate of the
Maori race ...
materially depends.

Source: Pioneer Missionary Among the Maoris, A
Author: GRACE
Quote:
Then followed a long
discussion on the
land question, all
the arguments in
common use amongst
the Maoris being
[144] brought forth.
Notes: T.S.Grace Journal in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928)

Author: BAINES
Quote:
Ah! `that land
question' was always
a source of trouble
in New Zealand, like
anything else when
the ownership is
uncertain.

Author: SENIOR
Quote:
Old colonists in New
Zealand ... are
divided amongst
themselves upon the
land question ...

... a struggle for
control of the land,
and the land
question involved
the native question
and the system of
precarious military
alliances
establihsed by
Fitzroy.

Author: HAWTHORNE
Quote:
Most of the natives
were Hauhaus of
1865, who had become
once more
exceedingly
disaffected, owing
to the non-solution
of the land
question.

The landrail also is
another example of a
slow flying bird
with considerable
expanse of wing for
its weight, but with
short primaries.
Notes: http://rsnz.natlib.govt.nz/volume/rsnz_05/rsnz_05_00_000730.html Transactions and Proceedings of the Royal Society of New Zealand ART. XVI ..By CAPTAIN F. W. HUTTON, C.M.Z.S. page 143[Read before the Auckland Institute, 19th August, 1872.]

Quote:
The following are
proposed to be added
to the list of birds
to be protected:-
Kaka, native thrush,
fantail, wren,
tomtit, robin,
fernbird, cuckoo,
paradise duck, blue
heron, kingfisher,
oyster-catcher,
redbill, landrail
and swamprail.

Our representative of the restricted genus Rallus (R. assimilis) resembles closely an Australian species, but is distinguishable [18] by the pectoral band and rufous colouring of the head and neck being less prominent. This is the Land Rail' of the colonists.
RALLUS PHILIPPENSIS. (BANDED RAIL.) ... Native names. Patatai, Popotai, Mohotai, Moho-patatai, Moho-pereru, and Puohotata; `Land-Rail' of the colonists.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Pepe ... Rallus philippensis assimilis, banded or land rail. Ibid. 311 Pu[u]ohotata, Rallus philippensis, banded or land rail, a bird.... Pu[u]ohotata ... Rallus philipensis assimilis, banded or land rail; a bird. Ibid. 322 Puohotata, ... Hypotaenidia philippensis; land rail, a bird.

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: BANDED RAIL Rallus philippensis Other names: Landrail, Striped Rail, Mohopereru, Mioweka. (The old sealers' name for the Macquarie Island race was Wigeon!)

Author: O'SULLIVAN
Quote:
... Skull worked
with the Hories /
who were O.K. so
long as their
tight-arse worries /
over land rights and
such didn't throw
them in flurries /

The proposal for the
disposal of the
Maori lands.. would
play into the hands
of the land rings...
Sir George Grey's
statements and
accusations about
the Canterbury land
ring were a fallacy.

When land rings got
large tracts of the
country into their
hands, settlers,
when they wanted to
buy it, had to pay a
very stiff price ...

Much of the 50% rise
since Land Sales
control was lifted
is due to this [sc.
the remunerative
private enterprise
of buying houses for
speculative resale].

Source: Short History of New Zealand Life, A
Author: MORRELL
Quote:
To compensate its
settlers for the
trials and
disappointments they
had endured, it [the
NZ Co.] gave them
the right to select
more land. These
rights were in the
form of documents
called 'land scrip'.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
In Taranaki and on
the East Coast there
were sporadic Maori
feuds, during the
fifties, between the
land sellers and the
`land holders'; but
it seems probable
that the great
majority of Maoris,
south of Auckland,
sympathized with the
latter party.

Until statesmen take
the place of
politicians, this
sort of thing is
likely to continue
and land settlement
is as far off as
ever.

I claim that what is
wanted to relieve
the present
stagnation is
progressive land
settlement. To get
the people back on
to the land should
be the chief aim of
the Government.

REHABILITATION ..
Some 16,000 men had
been demobilised in
recent months, and
only 25 of them had
been placed on the
land. Something
should be done to
hurry things along.
New Zealand had not
for many years had a
Minister of Lands
who understood land
settlement, and
possibly that was
why there was not
one word in the
Budget concerning
land settlement.

Mr. Massey said: -
"The Dominion may
rest assured that
the policy of the
new Ministry will be
both liberal and
progressive in the
highest and best
sense of the terms.
We intend to push
land settlement for
all we are worth.
..."

Not the slightest
attempt has ever
been made to bring
into existence a
decent land
settlement scheme
and to bring to the
Dominion the type
who would settle in
the country.

RETURNED SOLDIERS ..
Establishing of
Businesses. -The
association asks
that opportunity be
given to suitable
returned soldiers to
establish themselves
in business. In
this, as in all
other schemes, the
keynote is the
suitability of the
individual. It is
considered that this
is the natural
complement of the
land settlement
scheme at present in
operation.

It is obviously
ridiculous to say;
that in a country
like New Zealand,
which is producing
an increasing volume
of wealth, each
year, a definite and
comprehensive land
settlement scheme is
out of the question.

The chief causes of
discontent have been
the failure to
inaugurate the land
settlement scheme on
which the Party
pinned its faith to
solve the
unemployment
problem, the
futility of
purchasing
high-priced estates
to cut them up at
uneconomic figures,
and the uninspiring
compendium of
previously existing
legislation placed
by the Government on
the Statute Book
last session in the
name of a Land
Settlement Act.

The
government-sponsored
scheme was the

Author: McARA
Quote:
`Clips', `keps', or
landing chairs: A
solid, dead flush,
landing platform for
the cages was
required at each
level and at the
surface for getting
full trucks in and
out of cages. This
platform was
provided by a steel
frame mounted on
heavy bearers two or
three feet below the
level of the chamber
floor so that it
could be tilted into
the shaft by a lever
and make a strong
support beneath the
cages. It was
balanced by a
counterweight to
make it easy to
operate. To ensure
that the two cages
in the shaft worked
exactly opposite
each other when the
chamberman `changed
gear' to wind ore
from a different
level, he rang the
change signal of
five bells on the
steel-wire
knocker-line
suspended in the
shaft compartment,
and the
engine-driver placed
the `free' cage on
the surface `clips'
(or `keps') and
disengaged it on the
engine drive-shaft.
The chamberman then
signalled to lift
the `fast' cage on
the level where he
was working just
clear of the clips,
and pinned these
back clear of the
shaft. He entered
the `fast' cage and
rang the number of
the level to which
he wished to change,
and was taken there
by the driver. On
arrival at the level
he placed the clips
in position in the
shaft and rang the
change signal,
whereupon the driver
placed the `fast'
cage on the clips
and put the `free'
cage (which was
sitting on the
surface clips) in
gear on the engine
drive-shaft. Thus,
when the cage was
raised from the
level to the
surface, the cage
from the surface
would be exactly at
the level from which
the winding was
taking place. Great
care had always to
be taken to ensure
that the clips were
not left protruding
into the shaft as a
serious accident
could result if the
cage crashed into
them.

shingle central
laneway, electric
fencing and water in
all paddocks.

Subdivided into 22
main paddocks, the
farm has a high
quality gravel
all-weather laneway
and sound shelter
belts.

Te Kura is easily
worked with, with
metalled laneways on
the flats ...

Since then, he has
also solved the
problem of access to
parts of the farm
cut off by a series
of bush-filled
gorges by building
laneways through
them.

So, he built a
system of laneways
linking more than
200 paddocks, five
main sets of yards,
three woolsheds,
four cattle yards
and 13 docking
yards.

I paid this without
language because
there were ladies
present...

That's what I keep
telling the language
Nazis over the last
10 years.

Author: DAVIES
Quote:
The pre-school
centre gave [Maori
children] the
confidence needed to
enter the pakeha
culture. It is good
to know that now, in
a number of areas,
Maori pre-schools,
Te Kohanga Reo
(Language Nests),
are providing that
confidence within
Maori culture.

Extension to house
Cook Island nest
[heading] A hall is
to be extended on
Wellington's town
belt land so a Cook
Islands language
nest can be
established.

nests now. Kohanga
reo

CAULOPSETTA SCAPHA (Forster). Megrim . Known as `witch' or `lantern-fish' at Napier. Taken by trawlers in sandy localities as far north as Hauraki Gulf. Not popular as a food fish. ... Distribution: New Zealand coasts (unknown North Auckland Peninsula).

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: NEW ZEALAND MEGRIM or WITCH (MAHUE) Caulopsetta scaphus (Bloch and Schneider). In Napier it is known as Lantern-fish, but for what reason I am unable to say, unless it is from the peculiar transparency when it/is held up to a strong light. Another name given to this useless fish by local fishermen, in Port Chalmers at least, was that of Cadger's-fish.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
MEGRIM ... Sometimes
called Lantern-fish
(because a lantern
could be easily
shone through it)
and known to the
Maoris as `mahue' -
the fish that is
left behind. Known
to Christchurch
fishermen in early

handed out to
well-known bludgers

docks to cadge fish.

A little wiry herb,

is similarly
green-veined inside,
when viewed from
beneath.

That our closest

The workers don't

Axing or restricting

The coining of the
word "larrikin"
iscredited to an
Irish sergeant of
thepolice in
Melbourne... "What's
he beendoing now,
sergeant?" said
theMagistrate. "He
was a larrikin
(a-larking) about in
the streets,
yourWorship." "A
what?"... "A
larrikin, sor."

This time the brand
is Tau Henare,
larrikin, cowboy,
fighter.

Author: MARSHALL
Quote:
He said it was
vicious interference
from that cheeky
young larrikin in
the Labelling
Department ...

Author: HALEY

When Dad was a young
larrikin he and all
his mates used to
race up and down the
tideline in their

Author: BELL
Quote: Let clodhoppers plough, then, and harrow;/ Let larrikins loiter at flax. Ibid.124 The soulless larrikins of your street-corners - the blackguard barrackers of your football fields; for these are they.

Lounging Leary
Larrikins Lashed -
the Decay in British
Manhood. Have you
ever made a study of
the hooligan of the
Antipodes, our own
binging, leary,
larrikin

This [Dunedin]
individual began to
deal out what the
larrikins call a
`stouch` to the two
unfortunate females.

Author: BAUCKE
Quote:
The larrikin [in
Queen Street]
stoppeth to invent
appropriate
blasphemy; ...

It is only fair to
state that prominent
members of the
Melrose Club
entirelydissociate
themselves from the
tactics adopted by
the half-a-dozen
larrikins on this
occasion, ...

The larks of the
leary larrikin are
becoming a menace to
the peace and
comfort of citizens
and a source of
annoyance and loss
to city restaurant
keepers.

It [Hooligan] at
first typified a
cross between a
London rough and a
Cockney tough, which
are two terms for
two but slightly
different things,
which have only the
semblance of a shade
of a shadow of
difference, and are
both akin to our
Australasian
larrikin. A larrikin
is not necessarily a
loafer or a
criminal, though he
is often, if not
invariably, a member
of a push which may,
and usually does,
contain a certain
criminal element,
and a still larger
element verging
towards criminality.

Author: MANSFIELD
Quote:
And where did a girl
like that go to in a
place like this. ...
She supposed Alice
had picked up some
horrible common
larrikin and they'd
go off into the bush
together.

war, pretending that

larrikin, larakin n.

the larrikins

larrikin ... n.
hoodlum, hooligan,

The man who once

Some [business

suits the New
Zealand psyche well.
We like a touch of

Author: McGill
Quote:
He could see nothing

Probably larrikins

There were sailors

gang called the

enough police.

Author: PARK
Quote:
The white larrikins
jammed on their flat
hats and scurried

larickins ... ne'er

Author: HARPER
Quote:
We are beset with
larrikins [in
Hokitika] who lurk
about in the
darkness and deliver
every sort of attack
on the walls and
roof with stones and
sticks.

The people of Otago
have no intention
whatever of spending
their revenue in
educating Auckland
larrikans or
supporting indolent
officials in
Wellington.

Author: HAY
Quote:
The Auckland
`larrikin`is a
growing nuisance,
but he is neither so
numerous nor so
objectionable as his
folloe in Melbourne
or Sydney. Unlike
the street-arab, he
is either a
schoolboy, or earns
his living somehow,
or he is a truant
from work of either
kind. He
hasexuberant spirits
and an inordinate
love of mischief
..... He has a sort
of organisation of
his own, and seems
to revel in uncurbed
liberty of action.

The chance
mispronunciation of
a colloquial word,
by a Melbourne
police officer, has
added a new term to
our language in the
colonies. Who
amongst us has not
heard of the
`larrikin'? He is
essentially
colonial, English
cities may have
`gamins` and the
Pacific Slope can
boast of `hoodlums`
... Though everybody
speaks and writes
about the
`larrikin', what is
he? ... I presume, I
may say, he is of
the male sex and
that his age ranges
from 12 to 21. He is
oftown origin. His
amusements are
various. He likes to
be in the streets,
and rather prefers
to be about
theatres. Smoking is
his pastime. As to
his actions the
larrikins may be
classed under two
headings: 1) The
mischievous larrikin
2) the criminal
larrikin.

Notes: letter by John Cassells, former policeman with Dalton (Griffiths Collection)

Author: HOPEFUL
Quote:
The youth of both
sexes have far too
much run of the
streets, and the
`larrikin,' as the
rising young man is
called, is often a
mischievous specimen
of later manhood,
and his street
liberty degenerates
into vice.

There is also a
decrease in the
number of offences
that might be
classed as acts of
larrikins, and
larrikinism ... is
not so prevalent.

LaraZ.ri-kin
(l&abreve.raZ.r&ibreve.aZ.k&ibreve.n),
n. [Cf. prov. Eng.
larrick lively,
careless, larack to
frolic, to romp. See
Note below] 1. A
street blackguard; a
rowdy. 2. A
hobbledehoy inclined
to rough horseplay
and practical
joking. 3. In a
general sense, an
ill-bred or
low-minded person; -
often used merely as
a contemptuous
epithet. 4. A
neglected boy who
frequents the
streets; a street
Arab; a gutter
snipe. Marcus
Clarke. In senses 1
and 2 this word has
become common
inEngland. Larrikin
is thought to have
come into use about
1870. Its origin,
though much
disputed, is
commonly explained
by the following
anecdote : An Irish
policeman at
Melbourne, on
bringing a notorious
rough into court,
was asked by the
magistrate what the
prisoner had been
doing, and replied,
"He was a-larriki'
[i. e., a-larking]
about the streets."
This story lacks
confirmation, but
the word may not
improbably be
connected with lark
to frolic, to which,
indeed, the Prov.
Eng. larrick and
larrack are perhaps
related.

Author: CROWTHER (ed.)
Quote:
Larrikin groups,
though not common,
were also observed
[in Cathedral
Square,
Christchurch, 20 Apr
1956]. Numbers of
noisy youths and
girls congregated
for short [6]
periods and engaged
in loud conversation
and laughter.

[Hdg] TWO LARRIKINS
PUT ON PROBATION.
`This is not an
ordinary case of
burglary, but rather
irresponsible
larrikinism,` the
Magistrate told the
youths.

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote:
Brought from England
by the early
settlers or flowing
thence in later days
.us;are: quid for a
pound sterling,
larrikin and
hooligan for roughs,
getting the wind up,
for donkey's years,
and quod for prison.

~ n. a boodlum, a
hooligan, a rowdy;
whence larrikinism,
the behavious of
larrikins.

Author: MITCHELL
Quote:
larrikin: Young
people of whom you
happen not to
approve. Note that
all the terms of
disapprobation for
rumbustious youth
left the rest of the
world when youth
took it over and
crawled off to die
in New Zealand where
the old have such a
strong hold.
Expressions still
used are `milk-bar
cowboy', `flagon
wagon gang' and even
occasionally `Teddy
boy.'

Author: CLEARY
Quote:
... but what can one

and nobody to

In two minutes each
of these bikies has
a heavy hand on his
neck. ...

Quote:
larrikin -
larrikinism: A

YOUNG MAN.

VANDALISM ( see:
yahoo, yob-yobbo)

Lucky we found it

larrikin n. Austral.

Author: BINNEY
Quote:
Some larrikin had
gone and bust the

Author: JONES
Quote:
Gilmore worried that

frightening off

Source: Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success
Quote:
This was great for a
young larrikin like
me as it gave me an
immense amount of
freedom to roam the
hills and rivers and
create all sorts of
adventurous
pastimes, some real,
most imagined in my
highly ceative mind.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
... the sound of
children's voices
.... not the
melodious voices of

.... but the voices
of Colonial
`larrikins',
healthy, loud, and

Author: DUCHESS OF BUCKINGHAM
Quote:
The `larrikins', as
we called the young
and giddy portion of
this crew [who had
landed to explore

the bush
impenetrable.

Author: MORRIS
Quote:
The word has various
shades of meaning
between a playful
youngster and a
blackguardly rough.
Little street-boys
are often in a
kindly way called
little larrikins.
(See quotations),
1870 and 1885.)
Archibald Forbes
described the
larrikin as `a cross
between the Street
Arab and Hoodlum,
with a dash of the
Rough thrown in to
improve the
mixture.`
(`Century.') The
mostexalted position
yet reached in
liteature by this
word is in Sir
Richard Burton's
Translation of the
Arabian Nights'
(1886-7), vol. i. p.
4, Story of the
larrikin and the
Cook; vol. iv. p.
281, Tale of First
Larrikin. The
previous translator,
Jonathan Scott, had
rendered the Arabic
word, Sharper.
-->There are three
views as to the
origin of the word,
viz.-->(I) That it
is a phonetic
spelling of the
broad Irish
pronunciation, with
a trilled rof the
word larking). The
story goes that a
certain Sergeant
Dalton, about the
year 1869, charged a
youthful prisoner at
the Melbourne Police
Court with being `
a-larrr-akin' about
the streets.` The
police Magistrate,
Mr Sturt, did not
quite catch the
word- `A what,
Sergeant?` -`A
larrikin', your
Worchup.` The police
court reporter used
the word the next
day in the paper,
and it stuck. (see
quotation, `Argus,'
1896.) This story is
believed by 99
persons out of 100:
unfortunately it
lacks confirmation;
for the record of
theincident cannot
be discovered after
long search in files
by many people. Mr
Skeat's warning must
be remembered -
-->`As a rule,
derivations which
require a story to
be told turn out to
be false.` -->(2)
That the word is
thieves' English,
promoted like swag,
plant, lift, etc.,
into ordinary
Australian English.
Warders testify that
for a number of
years before the
word appeared in
print, it was used
among criminals in
gaol as two separate
words, viz.
leary('cute, fly,
knowing), and
kinchen(youngster),
`learykinchenshortened
commonly into
`leary-kin' and
leary kid'.
Australian wardens
and constables are
Irish, almost to a
man. Their
pronunciation of
`leary kin' would be

The word has been

This became in
English larry, to
which the English
diminutive, kinwas
added; although this
etymology is always
derided in
Melbourne.

Author: POTTS
Quote: ' Athene Albifacies , wekau of the Maoris, is known by some up-country settlers as the big owl or laughing jackass.' -->`The cry of the laughing jackass ... Why it should share with one of our petrels and the great Dacelo of Australia the trivial name of laughing jackass, we know not; if its cry resembles laughter at all, it is the uncontrollable outburst, the convulsive shout of insanity; we have never been able to trace the faintest approach to mirthful sound in the unearthly yells of this once mysterious night-bird.'

Quote: 232.a. Sceloglaux albifacies rufifacies Buller, 1904) North Island Laughing Owl ... North Island, probably extinct ... 232.b. Sceloglaux albifacies albifacies (Gray, 1844) Laughing Owl (Whekau)

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Extinct birds ... Laughing Owl Sceloglaux albifacies (GRAY, 1844) OTHER NAMES: Whekau, hakoke (North Island),rock owl. The `doleful shrieks' of the laughing owl, which varied seasonally, were heard incessantly on rainy nights. Apparently it was easily kept in captivity, and reports say that it cooeyed in the evening, yelped like a young dog and mewed and chuckled. ... The most recent record of sighting was at Manapouri in 1950 ...

A friend is

laughing owl.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Whekau, whekaukau, ... Sceloglaux albifacies, laughing owl.

Sceloglaux albifacies Gray. Laughing-owl. Mr. Clouston reports this species from one South Island locality. No other first-hand or reliable information is available. The undoubted diminution in the numbers of the laughing-owl is usually ascribed to the practical extinction of the `Maori' rat.

Various species of Rubus , a briar-like plant which is a nuisance to men in the bush. It also grows on moist or shady hillsides in the open and is a great danger to hoggets, as they get caught up in it. When growing in the open it is often called a l.-bush . Except in Potts's `Out in the Open', to the best of my knowledge a b.l. has always meant an argumentative fellow. ([1898 Morris Austral-English]) [Lawyer = `briar` is recorded as English from the sixteenth century. The reason for the name is obvious.--A.W.]

Author: PICKERING
Quote:
So to cope with the
rituals of tramping,
its pains and
camaraderie, a slang
language has
developed to suit.
Lots of quick short
words to fit in the
breathless pauses as
you pant uphill.
`Crud' (cloud),
`bush-bash', a
`gunn' tramper
(which must have
originated from Davy
Gunn's famous trek
up the Hollyford
Valley to help
victims of a plane
crash in 1936; he
travelled 40 km by
rowing boat, horse
and foot in 21
hours), `windfall'
(a collapsed pile of
trees), `pit' (the
tramper's true
friend, a sleeping
bag), `pog'
(porridge), `bastard
grass' and `lawyer'
(two unpleasant
plants), `piker'
(one who stayed
home), `Huey'
(all-powerful god of
weather), and many,
many more.

They went through
the thickest places
matted with
supplejacks and
lawyers.

The whole of this
area was thick
bush.. as far as St.
David street, and
from that locality
along the edge of
the stream
impenetrable from
creepers, lawyers,
and supplejacks.

The fuschia and
lawyers are all
coming out in
blossom.

Quote:
He hit a young
horopito and it shot
him across into a
bunch of lawyer like
a dirty great coil
of winch-rope.

branches and

backs of its leaves
are covered with
these barbs.

LawaZ.yer (laaZ.y&etilde.r), n. [Add.] 3. [Prov. Eng.lawyer a bramble, the thorny stem of a brier.] (Bot.) (a) In New Zealand, any one of various trailing brambles (esp. Rubus australis ) which impede locomotion in the bush; - called also lawyer cane. (b) In Australia, the liliaceous plant Flagellaria Indica; - called also lawyer vine . Both plants are called also bush lawyer.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Lawyer ... One of the English provincial uses of this word is for a thorny stem of a briar of bramble. In New Zealand, the name is used in this sense for the Rubus australis , N.O. Rosaceae , or Wild Raspberry-Vine (Maori, Tataramoa ). The words Bush-Lawyer, Lawyer-Vine , and Lawyer-Palm , are used with the same signification, and are also applied in some colonies to the Calamus australis , Mart. (called also Lawyer-Cane), and to Flagellaria indica , Linn., similar trailing plants. [Aus 1885]
Climbing forest plants or `lianes' are abundantly represented by the lawyer [fn Rubus australis.], Parsonsia albiflora , Convolvulus,

get a tooth out. Can
you lay me on to a
good dentist.

Source: English as it is spoken in NZ
Author: BENNETT
Quote:
A systems of
hire-purchase called
the `Lay-by' has
resulted in the verb
`layby', pronounced
and written as one
word.

(Footrot Flats) [Wal
says] (Mutter) OKAY,
SO I LAYED ONE ON
THE BEGGAR! (Mumble)
WARNED THE
JERSEY-PULLIN' SLOB
I'D DROP HIM!
(Mutter) B----Y
ONE-EYED REF'!
(Whine).

Author: HAY
Quote:
Pig! Pig! Lay up
there dogs! good
dogs! ... [331] The
dogs are at [the
pigs] gallantly,
seizing them by the
ears, laying up
against them flank
to flank.

Author: ROCHFORT
Quote:
He earned a scanty
living by
manufacturing the
New Zealand flax,
and laying it up in
ropes, cords, &c.

They [Pete and Sam]
got up the low
scree, sidled across
the first face ...
but they were
getting bombed ...
Pete had a dekko up
a chimney. But there
was a lay-back ...

The driver takes the
trucks through the
mine races, and
deposits them in
lay-bys, places
similar to ...
railway sidings.
Here the trucks are
received by the
hangers-on, boys who
attach the trucks to
an endless rope.

(Bell and Fraser:
Waihi-Tairua) In the
Grand Junction Mine
... electrically
driven fans, placed
in `lay-bys` in the
underground road
ways, have been
found effective.

Author: DEVANNEY
Quote:
At the point where
the bord left the
dip a `lay-by` was
put in. This was a
double road [taking]
full trucks on one
side ... and
[empties on the
other].

Author: PEARSON
Quote:
The four of them
walked along the
tunnel, past the
main lay-by where
another trucker was
sending off the last
boxes.

Author: THOMPSON
Quote:
Two shifts a day she
[sc. the mine-horse]
would drag upwards
of 200 half-tonne
boxes, six at a
time, into the
lay-by, where Frank
... would jig them
down to the next
level. [41] About
once every three
months she would ...
[run] wide on one of
the corners in such
a way as to pull all
theboxes off the
line.

[Advt] No laybys. No
rainchecks. Stock
may vary from store
to store.

Author: BURCHFIELD
Quote:
Sometimes would have
to be done about the
word `lay-by.` In
Britain it meant a
roadside bay where
vehicles could be
pulled off the road.

Author: LELAND
Quote:
lay-by: The LAY-AWAY
with time to pay at
your friendly
department store.

lay-by ... 4.
Chiefly Austral. &
N.Z. a system of
payment whereby a
buyer pays a deposit
on an article, which
is reserved for him
until he has paid
the full price.

Author: MANTELL
Quote:
Yes. That's it. A
time payment card.
...So that the lower
case letters `yby'
could be part of the
word `layby', not
part of an address.

Author: WATSON
Quote:
I can remember
putting one [skirt]
on layby and paying
it off over the
weeks.

Other definitions:
telephone box
(booth); layby
(layaway); boarding
cattery (kennel for
cats); inward goods
(deliveries); ...
dormitory town
(bedroom community)
...
Notes: 1986 B.G. Ostmann U.S. food-writer's written remarks: p.c.Tui Flower NZ Woman's Weekly (14 Jan 1987)

Quote:
layby small deposit
securing goods from
sale until depositor
pays the balance
(usually
progressively) and
uplifts the goods;
generally operated
by drapers and
department stores.

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote:
Goods may be bought
on a layby system.

There were no credit
cards; we paid for
our purchases with
cash. If you didn't
have enough cash you
put the purchases on
lay-by and paid it
off.

Layby Now [headline]
We all want to beat
GST, but with money
invested we all want
to wait until
September 30, ... By
paying a deposit
now, we will set up
your boat motor,
dinghy, etc,
fordelivery on or
near September 30.

We went and lay-byed
a fridge-freezer and
a Gentle Annie
automatic washing
machine.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Some of the typical
terms used in
marbles referred to
the act of shooting
and the movement of
the marbles. Those
related to ways of
shooting marbles
were cribbing,
firsts, fudging,
funks, funnicks,
funnigans, flunks,
forces, knee-high,
knuckle-down-stiff,
knuckles, and lasts.
Termsconnected with
the movement of the
marbles were:
cannons, clears,
dead-stick,
double-hits, fires,
funs, gees,
haystacks, in smug,
keeps, kills,
kisses, lay-ups,
manyes, ones, pink,
ringer, rolls, scat,
screws, skinned,
skun, spiders,
sported-off, stays,
stops, tracks,
throughs.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Here are some
[marble] terms from
Taranaki around
1880-1890: firsts,
lay-up, stakes,
tips, sticking-taw,
nothings, anythings,
fade-it, knuckledown
stiff, dubs, finking
[sic, ?funking],
sips, spanning,
placing; and from
Dunedin School in
1949: knee high,
manyies, tracks,
screws, nuts,
sleets, kills,
forces, dig, dubs,
cheats.

Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
I was much
interested in Mr M
-'s method of
'laying down' his
paddocks in
artificial grasses.
Notes: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies (1935)

Quote:
For this reason
special
paspalum-paddocks
should not be laid
down with paspalum
alone. In laying
down a special
paspalum-paddock ...

Source: Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I
Author: TAIT
Quote:
.. through the
laying down of good
pasture wherever the
hilly country would
permit.

Author: AYSON
Quote:
He used to enter
into competition
with other
heavyweights in the
district pulling at
the `lazy stick.'

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: The athletic games of strength include Bull in the Ring, Buck Jumping, Cock-Fighting, Honey Pots, Heave-Ho, King of the Castle, No Man Standing, ... and Lazy Stick. Ibid. 2/769 Action terms related to the movements of the marbles are, Throughs and No Throughs, Tracks and Clears, Stops and Rolls, Lay-Up, Manyies, Kiss, Ons, Gees, Haystacks, Stays, Spiders Can't Cross a River etc. Action Terms related to taking an opponent's marbles are Fires, Double-Hits and Forces.

Author: DAVIN
Quote:
[?Irish] So the next
thing was he'd got
Mark Hogan into an
argument about
strength and then
they were hard at it
with the lazy-stick
on the floor.

Author: EVANS
Quote:
The lazy stick was
also another event
contested [at
Waikaka] but little
is heard of it now.
... How many broom
handles they broke
or crowbars they
bent pulling the
lazy-stick does not
bearmention.

June: All hoggets to
go on to winter
feed. Ploughing of
lea [at Glenaray,
Canterbury].

Author: KERSE
Quote:
Ploughing the lea
was usually done in
June, and often in
frosty conditions,
as I remember my
ploughing days at
North Chatton.

[Mr Mee from ?Becks,
Central Otago
speaking] Turning
our lea-ground [li:
graund] in for the
winter [before the
ground gets too hard
to plough].

It kills other pests
besides the leach.

Author: WEKEY
Quote:
The mere prevalence
of blocks of
`cement', as it is
technically termed,
... forms no sure
indication of the
presence of a lead,
but if the `cement'
be found strewn over
a limited tract,
round which the
bed-rock crops out
... it may then be
taken as a guide in
prospecting.

Author: HARPER
Quote:
.. we came to
several shafts sunk
about eighty feet on
a `lead' of gold
lately discovered.
Gold here [West
Coast] is usually
found in strata,
about three feet
thick of washdirt
...

Alluvial gold occurs
in well-defined
`leads', of which
there are three
distinct kinds,
without including
the local sluicing
diggings

Author: MORRIS
Quote:
~ (pronounced leed),
a mining term. In
the Western United
States and
elsewhere, the term
leadin mining is
used as equivalent
for lode. In
Australia, the word
leadis only used in
reference to
alluvial mining, and
signifies the old
river-bed in which
gold is found.
[1875]

Author: PFAFF
Quote: These [black sand] leads yielded a richer return ... than probably any other alluvial workings in New Zealand ... ibid. 79 I worked a claim on the Scandinavian Hill ... This lead was about 600 yards long, and the wash varied from 1 foot to 4 feet.

~ v.t.-n. the old
river-bed in which
gold is found.-v.t.
to strike the lead,
to find a river bed
containing gold; to
succeed. -lead'ers
n. pl. of a bullock
team, the leading
pair.

Author: BLYTH
Quote:
Lead: A defined
gutter of auriferous
wash.

Author: MILLER
Quote:
I was on gold all
the time. I had sunk
my first prospect
hole at the lower
end of a shallow
depression ... and
had struck the
deepest part of the
lead. It was a
narrow gutter, no
more than afoot wide
at the most, and
rich in heavy gold.

Author: MAY
Quote:
LEAD: a well-defined
bed of auriferous
wash-dirt. Used
narrowly, a lead was
in a gully, creek,
or terrace and its
course could not be
determined by the
trend of the surface
and the existing
drainage system.

Previously worked
soil had been
brought up to allow
of further
examination of the
`lead' of bones
under the rock.
Notes Hamilton
`Avian Remains'

Lead cows will
usually be lined up
ready to walk on.

Author: PULLEN
Quote:
We had a lead dog
now called Steel.

Author: LILICO
Quote:
[The dogs] would
head, lead, hunt
away, force and back
....

Author: HARTLEY
Quote:
The dog `Trojan' ...
would head, hunt,
lead, back, heel
cattle, catch a
horse, pick up cast
sheep, open and
close gates,
retrieve sacks ...,
strike sheep with
his paws, walk on
his hind legs, ring
a bell and perform
many other minor
tricks.

Lead. - (1) The head
shepherd, or whoever
is in charge of the
musterers, is said
to l. them.

The lead from the
yards is circular
and uphill just
before entering the
dip which is like a
60 ft. washing tray.

They made a `lead'
in the stockyard for
branding the cattle.
This was something
like a `race' for
branding sheep with
a swing gate .....
It had a wide
entrance gradually
getting narrower and
narrower till it
became a lane only
just wide enough for
one beast at a time
to squeeze through
... Five or six
would he jammed in
at one time ... the
gate at each end
being closed .... in
a few minutes each
lot could be
branded.

Lead. - (1) ... (2)
The front part of a
mob of sheep. (C.)

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
When the bailiffs
arrived, with the
bleating flock of
sheep, she turned
the lead, placed
herself ... between
the ford and the
sheep, and invited
them to cross. When
dusk fell, Mrs.
Parker still defied
the stringing of the
sheep across [the
river].

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
lead: the head of a
mob of sheep on the
move. Not
necessarily
physically the
strongest beast, but
a strong-willed one,
will take the lead.

Author: WRIGHT
Quote:
The engine beats and
the combine sings to
the drays that are
leading in/

Author: McKEE WRIGHT
Quote:
And the fork tines
flash as the sheaves
are turned on the
frame of the
one-horse dray; ...
the sheaves are
small and thin,/ The
engine beats and the
combine sings to the
drays that are
leading in,/

The term "lead
learners" appears to
be a new, probably
politically correct,
term for "teacher".

Author: RIDDOLLS
Quote:
Where the yards are
attached to the
shed, a lead-in race
to the shed must be
provided.

First heard it on
the Maheno in 1915
from a `Tommy' who
told me that before
the war he was
working at Day and
Martin's, of
blacking fame. `Ever
heard of them?' he
proudly asked me.
`No, I can't say
that I have,' I
replied. He gave me
such a look of pity
and scorn that I
could almost feel
myself shrivelling
up. `Gor blime,
chum, I worked for
them fifteen years,'
he said. `Yus,
fifteen years making
blacking, and my old
woman is deeping my
end up. Never heard
tell of them? `Leg
swinger,' chum,
that's what you
are.'

An Educational
scheme is under way
for the benefit of
:- (1) The Blue
Boys. (2) Lead
Swingers.

Sick parade in these
days was, to many, a
"leadswinger's"
paradise...

That "Bill the Dunk"
is a noted
lead-swinger, but
that he has the
happy knack of
feathering his own
bed to advantage.

P.U.'s. - See
`Lead-Swinging.'
Lead-Swinging. - See
P.U.'s - they can
tell you. The origin
of this term is
obscure - the
destination,
Blighty, or the
clink.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: FRIGATE MACKEREL Auxis thazard (Lacepede) ... This beautifully-shaped fish is known in Australia as the Frigate Mackerel. Fishermen there also call it Leadenall from the appearance of polished lead it presents when freshly caught.

Author: VICTORIAN MINER
Quote:
Any reefs that may
be found in this
part of the country
will not prove reefs
in the true sense of
the word, but mere
`spurs' or
`leaders', and these
much broken and full
of `faults'.

Four rich leaders of
gold-bearing quartz
LEADER.- A string or small vein which leads to the main reef, or is supposed to do so. Ibid. 82 BALLARAT, Moanatairi Creek. Four men's ground, ... Gold-bearing leaders.
LEADER.- A string or small vein which leads to the main reef, or is supposed to do so. Ibid. 82 BALLARAT, Moanatairi Creek. Four men's ground, ... Gold-bearing leaders.

The Golden Crown
leader runs right
through the claim;
...

Author: BAINES
Quote:
Our reef, or leader,
measuring only four
inches in thickness,
a drive for a
considerable
distance following
the course of the
gold-bearing quartz
had to be carried
out, ...

Author: HOLLOWAY
Quote:
The [West Coast]
Quartz veins that
have hitherto been
worked are what are
known as `leaders'
or offshoots from
the main reefs.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
LEADER: Horses yoked
in the lead; single
leader.
Notes: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson

Quote:
The leaders reached
the shore, and the
polers had just got
their footing when
the coach turned
over.

~ v.t.-n. the old
river-bed in which
gold is found.-v.t.
to strike the lead,
to find a river bed
containing gold; to
succeed. -lead'ers
n. pl. of a bullock
team, the leading
pair.

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
In the small river
Ashburton ... we had
a little
misunderstanding
[105] with the
bullocks; the
leaders ... slewed
sharply round, and
tied themselves into
an inextricable knot
with the polars
[sic], while the
body bullocks by a
manoeuvre not
unfrequent, shifted,
or as it is
technically termed,
slipped, the yoke
under their necks,
and the bows over;
the off bullock,
turning upon the
near side, and the
near bullock upon
the off.

Author: COOPER
Quote:
The movements, so to
speak, of the
leaders are very
eccentric.

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
They [grasshoppers]
actually stopped a
bullock-team this
week. The big-winged
fellows kept flying
into the faces of
the leaders ...; and
the `bullocky' had
to take his team
back to the
homestead and unyoke
them.
Notes: c1872 in c1875 Meredith Adventuring in Maoriland (1935)

Author: WILSON
Quote:
They yoked up the
Bullocks today,
after some trouble
they got the leaders
and two behind them
in but drove the
others.
Notes: 1874 May 13 J.G.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 190

Author: WHITWORTH
Quote:
I let my leaders go,
and jumped down and
cut wheelers [sic]
traces and let them
go too ...

Author: CHAMIER
Quote:
... he could [with a
whip] ... tickle the
ear of the leader,
or flip a fly from
off the rump of a
poler.

My ploughman upset
his dray ... The
leaders got away
leaving the shafter
on his back.

Leaders. - The two
front bullocks of a
team, which had to
be specially broken
in for this work.
(Butler A First Year
in Canterbury
Settlement], p.95)

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
In 1867 there were
many wagons on the
road bearing huge
freights from
Dunedin to the
diggings, but
Thomson still
adhered to his
faithful dray with
its tilt over it,
and drawn by three
horses, one shafter
and two leaders.

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
(Joe Gasparich,
Northland kauri
country) The pair in
front [160]were the
leaders; they
answeredcommands
immediatelly ... At
the back of the team
were the `chainers'.

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
It was interesting
to watch the
leaders. The pair in
front [sc. of the
bullock team] were
the leaders, they
answered commands
immediately, and the
bullocky could get
them to do all sorts
of things.

Source: High Times in the High Country
Author: KERR
Quote:
When we had the last
mob of the day we'd
try to batter them
into submission,
tire them out in the
heat, march them up
to the top of the
hill and march them
down again like Old
King Cole, dog them
constantly. We aimed
for a nucleus of
docile leaders.

Nail, lead-head-
Nail having a lead,
cup-shaped head
which makes a
fastening
water-resistant
between the roofing
and the nail.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
At this stage I was
able to put my good
leading dog out to
the front to control
the pace of the
leaders ...

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
When trucking time
arrived the decoys
would be put back
inside the paddock
and the wild cattle
mustered to them ..
The leading dogs
would take up their
position ...

Author: WHYTE
Quote:
A slack leading dog
is worse than no dog
in the lead, for he
only 'sucks' the
sheep along with
him.

Author: PARKER
Quote:
I wanted to be like
one of those digs
the drovers call a
'leading dog', one
who always runs in
front of the flock
of sheep ..minding
the crossroads and
gateways ...

Author: SHARPE
Quote:
With a leading dog
ahead of the mob, on
a road without
traffic or open
gates, droving was
one of the best of
fine-weather jobs.

Author: MILLS
Quote:
One day I came upon
a large mob of
cattle, weary and
footsore. the
leading dog had
little to do.

Author: WATT
Quote:
It was called a
leading dog and was
very clever, leading
the sheep along, but
holding them up if
they went too fast.

Author: PULLEN
Quote:
We had a lead dog
now called Steel.
[lead dog; leader
dog]

Author: SCOTT
Quote:
We had no `leading'
dog

Leading Dog.- A dog
trained to run ahead
of a mob of sheep to
keep them steady.
Sheep drivers always
use them; but hill
shepherds do not
like their dogs to
learn to lead, as it
is supposed to make
them slack in
pulling sheep. (C.)

Author: MASTERS
Quote: First of all, on account of his colour, I would pick up Snow, one of Athol's three grand leading dogs. Ibid. 219 Once all were in, Athol would give a low whistle; the leading dogs would vanish.

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote:
Leading Dog: Some
`heading' dogs have
a natural aptitude
for leading sheep.
They are trained to
work at the head of
a mob of sheep and
keep them in check.
This is a most
useful dog when
droving sheep.

Leading dog: Dog
used to go in front
of a mob to control
its speed and stop
it breaking or
stampeding.

leading dog NZ &
Austral. dog used to
go in front of mob
of sheep to control
its speed.

Author: CARR
Quote:
Stooking and Leading
in. - The oat,
wheat, and barley
crops are ready ...
Driving the binder
requires experience.
Men are wanted ...
for stooking, i.e.,
picking up two
sheaves and
placingtheir heads
together at an angle
of about 45 degrees,
10 to 12 sheaves are
generally put in one
lot. ... There are
... good and bad
stookers after years
of experience...
Leading in. - When
the grain has been
long enough in
stook, it is loaded
on to drays ... and
carted to the stack
or mill ... The man
driving the dray is
called the
leader-in, and the
man who leads him,
the forker.

Mild-mosaic,
rugose-mosaic,
aucuba-mosaic,
leaf-drop,
stipple-streak,
spindle-tuber,
curly-dwarf,
leaf-roll, streak
and wildings are all
present in
New-Zealand-grown
commercial lines.
The Phasmidae , known also as `stick-insects and `leaf-insects', have their headquarters in the Malay Archipelago, but are spread over all the warm parts of the earth ...

~ n. an insect, the
wing cases of which
resemble a leaf.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: LEAFLESS LAWYER ( Rubus squarrosus ) Native perennial carrying many rearward facing spines and usually only small remnants of leaves.

Author: C-6
Quote: Rubus cissoides leafless lawyer
muehlenbeckia, leafless [s] Muehlenbeckia ephedroides Hook.f.

Author: BUDDLE
Quote:
Second - The land
Question. To prevent
further alienation
of Native lands is
the great object of
the league, and on
this point the
kingites carry with
them the sympathies
of the majority.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
... if we could view
the question from a
national Maori point
of view we should
find much to approve
of in the principle
of the League.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
This suggestion is
said to have led to
an offer to the
chief named to
become king of the
federated tribes,
but here again the
leaguers met with a
refusal.

[heading] NZ
leaguies are spread
to the far corners
of Britain...

The guys have been a
great help because
they had to accept
me as a leaguey. You
have got to remember
I am a leaguey who
came over and they
could have made it
hard for me.

Most of the leakers
are in areas such as
Sacramento
Apartments down on
the flat and
confined to houses
without eaves and
inferior cladding.

Leaky buildings were
prevalent in these
two areas, meaninng
prices of non-leaky
homes were driven up
by the shortage of
that type of house,
Mr Hickey said.

I am angry again
that, once again,
timber treatment is
being blamed as the
main cause of the
leaky building
syndrome.

Although a
proportion of
intensive units have
been affected by the
leaky building
syndrome, research..
showed that
residents were
generally satisfied
with most aspects of
this form of urban
living.

The Government has
its hands on a
report that's tipped
to reveal the leaky
home problem is
vastly more serious
than previously
estimated.

Pakuranga College
principal Heather
McRae said a two
storey block
containing up to 10
classrooms had been
confirmed as a
leaker and reports
had been
commissioned on
another two
buildings.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
I think the kitchen
is the chief glory
of the house,
boasting a
`Leamington range' -
[65] a luxury quite
unknown in these
parts, where all the
cooking is done on
an American stove, -
a very good thing in
its way, but
requiring to be
constantly attended
to.

[Ironmongery advt
includes] Fire
Guards Leamington
Ranges Open Fire
Scotch Ranges.

The house, with
lean-to, contained
seven appartments.

Source: Life & Recollections of an Early Colonist
Author: CARTER
Quote:
The house [of most
of the inhabitants
in the 1840s] was
divided into two
rooms, one on the
right the other on
the left, and was
frequently
supplemented with
the fashionable and
useful lean-to,
sometimes
constructed at one
end, but oftener in
the rear of these
truly convenient and
comfortable colonial
cottages, which
being generally
painted white,
looked neat, clean
andfresh.

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies

The pub leaner -

Up till then, New
Zealand hotel
patrons had a choice
between spartan
public bars -
consisting of lino
floors, bare walls
and stand-up tables
known as leaners -
and what was known
as the lounge bar,

more quaintly, the
ladies' and escorts'
lounge. (In the
trade it was
commonly called the

Author: CHARLES
Quote:
In the shearing shed
there is a strict
social order, ...
Below [the gun
shearers, the
professionals] are
the `learners' - men
and boys in their
first and second
seasons. Then the
shed-hands, in order
of experience and
ability, the
`fleecies' who pick
up the wool from the
shearing board, and
the `balers' who man
the presses.

The learners' chain
is called the monkey
chain, and the new
chaps are called
skulls, from the
chaffing at the
beginning: e.g.,
`Look at the skulls
on them!', `They've
got the right-shaped
headfor it'.
Learners retaliate
by calling the old
hands `lavatory
chains' or more
frequently
`shithouse chains'.
Notes: Feilding Freezing Works terms p.c. Colin Gordon

thechain. Even the

The various species of Celmisia , chiefly known by the settlers as cotton-grass orleather-plant, appear well adapted for our purpose.

house-cum-nurse cow
needs neither leg
rope nor bail: she
is milked in the
paddock.

Author: DONEY
Quote:
.. the cow should be
taken in hand at
calving, baled [sic]
and leg-roped ...

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
leg rope: a short
rope, not needed bay
all cows .. The term
may also be used as
a verb.

Author: ROBERTS
Quote:
.. we had to
headrope those
requiring branding
and after hauling
them up to a corner
post, leg-roped and
threw them on their
side.

In less time than it
takes to leg-rope a
cow, that meal of
steak and onions
disappeared.

I leg-roped her,
scraped the mud and
water off her
flanks..

We haven't leg-roped
a heifer out of 125
calved and the cups
always stay on.

She wanted to tempt
more drivers to stop
in the town. "We
might have to
leg-rope them yet,"
Mrs Rollinson said..

Author: WILSON
Quote:
`You don't see much
of women, Sim, do
you?' `... You want
to start picking
them over for years
before you leg-rope
one of them. They're
like any other
possession. ...'

Author: ROBERTS, WHS
Quote:
At Macfarlane's the
men saddled fresh
horses and rode in
some cattle which we
had a great bother
to yard, as
everything was new
... The yard was
divided into three -
one large and two
small - but as there
was no crush pen, or
drafting race, we
had to head rope
those
requiringbranding,
and after hauling
them up to a corner
post, leg-roped and
threw them on [44]
their side, placing
a long lever on
their neck and under
the lowest rail so
that they would not
move much ... When
released the poor
beast is not in an
amiable temper ...
So anyone in the
yard has to climb
the rails quickly
..., and the idea
that it may catch
you before your legs
are safely over the
cap rail certainly
accelerates one's
movements.
Notes: 1856 Dec 18 W.H.S. Roberts diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 43-

Quote:
When the milker has
bailed-up and
leg-roped the cow..
he should.. wash the
cow's udder and
teats and his hands.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
I fear I would have
defied to the death
Correspondence
School lessons, even

I reminded him of
nothing so much as

refusing to be

I'd been allowed to

from the night

attaching the

Author: FOSTON
Quote:
Each cow was to be
carefully leg-roped
.... Ted was shown

Author: GUTHRIE
Quote:
... they first of

...

He drives each cow
in her accustomed
turn from the yard
into the bail,
leg-ropes her,
washes teats with a
wet cloth,and
settles himself on a

v.tr. to tie an
animal by the hind
leg

leg-rope v.t. tie an

Quote:
[A cow named] Only
moved into the bail
and stood quietly
while John hooked
the holding chain

Author: HARTLEY
Quote:
If Dad appeared in

[A cow named] Only

the holdingchain

inthe wall. Only

The cups are

Quote:
Leg.- (1) Some dogs
get a bad habit of
biting sheep on the
l. in yards; others,
of laming other dogs
while fighting. Both
these vices are
called legging.

Legging: Slitting
the Skin of the
legs.

It was [in 1956] the
solo butchers who
were given the
tougher jobs like
legging and pelt
punching.

A dodge by owners
that should have
been worked out ages
ago is the legging
up of unfashionable
horsemen when they
want a horse
stopped, and then,
later on, when they
want to back him,
they put up a `big
gun.' It is
manifestly unfair to
the boys, but the
latter are compelled
to `hook 'em' as
they get so little
riding that four
quid is often very
handy to them.

Pick over the lambs'
wool. Pick out
stained wool, face
pieces, leggings,
and top-knots, as
thesewools make the
buyer suspicious ...

On the question of
leggings or leg pads
from below the
hocks, there is
often more
discussion than is
warranted.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
In the nineteenth
century the ring
game seems to have
been the most
popular marble game.
(In more recent
years marble games
with holes have had
the greater role.)
There was Big Ring,
in which a circle a
yard or more in
diameter was drawn
on the ground; there
was the mullibar
variation, in which
an outsize taw was
catapulted amongst
the marbles in this
circle. There were
Little Ring, Liney,
Follows, Follow the
Taw, Holey, and
then, on a less
important scale,
Butcher's Board, in
which the marbles
were bowled through
the holes in a
board,
Eye-Drop,Knock-Backs,
Leggings-Out (or
Leggin's-Out),
Span-'Em, and
Backits. The last
was more usually a
girls' game.

... Chris Smith
asked Billy Ibadulla
how to play leg
spin. Ibadulla ...
did what he could,
including bowling
him some leggies.

Quote:
In May, Governor
Fitzroy announced to

and means'.

Under the 1852

House of

...

It gives me quite a

taking a seat in
[168] that quiet,

Legislative Council.

Author: BARLOW
Quote:
... a Legislative
Council, consisting

... [fn] The
