Source: Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand
Author: HOCKEN
Quote: So passionate elsewhere was the popular feeling that with difficulty did Sir George Grey equip the new Legislative Council at [117] Wellington with its non-official members - `nominees' theywere called, a term which indeed became one of reproach. Ibid. 140 For the government of the Colony as a whole there were constituted the two Houses which at present exist - the Legislative Council and the House of Representatives, together constituting the General Assembly. The councillors were nominated by the Governor, in this respect resembling the old nominee system. They held their seats for life. As showing the fear and detestation in which the word `nominee' was held, Mr. Fox and others who assisted in passing the measure viewed the relating clauses as the great blots of the Act.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
The 1852
constitution was
extremely
democratic, more so
than those then in
force in the
Australian colonies.
The six Provincial
Councils, the House
of Representatives,
and the
Superintendents of
the Provinces were
all elective, though
the members of the
Legislative Council
(the Upper House)
were nominated for
life by the
Governor.

Author: BASSETT
Quote:
Legislative Council:
The upper chamber of
the New Zealand
Parliament, loosely
resembling the House
of Lords in Britain,
to which members
were appointed, not
elected. It was
abolished in 1949.

Author: McINTYRE
Quote:
At 2 p.m. assembled
in the Chamber of
the Legislative
Council both houses
together; higgeldy
piggeldy - an
unseemly
arrangement.

Author: JACKSON
Quote:
The Legislative
Council.. is
acknowledged to have
fairly won for
itself the
appellation of the
"Council of Old
Ladies."

No sane man can
suppose that any one
member of the
Cabinet believed
that in advising his
Excellency to call
Mr. Martin to the
Legislative Council,
he was securing an
addition to that
body of one who was
more fitted than his
fellows to fill so
responsible and
honorable an office.

The Legislative
Council had taken
two days to consider
whether or not a dog
should be killed
while they only took
three minutes to
consider whether or
not the Constitution
should be destroyed.

The Legislative
Council is the sort
of red-herring which
is sometimes found
very useful.

Mr. O'Conor asked
the Premier, whether
he will, this
Session, introduce a
bill to enable the
people of the colony
to elect members of
the Legislative
Council, either by
popular election or
by the local
governing bodies.

I think it is time
we should make the
Legislative Council
a more useful body
or else wipe it out
altogether.

This Bill is brought
in for the purpose
of creating a
Legislative Council
consisting of rich
men, who are
naturally Tories.

The second clause is
to abolish the
Legislative Council.

I say now that it is
a policy of the
Government to
abolish the
Legislative Council
as we have it today.

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote:
The Legislative
Council Abolition
Bill, introduced in

Quote:
The record of the

The late Legislative
Council was the

From the outset our

Every Friday night
you can see [this
ritual] in the lek
downtown, where
young bucks drive
around in their
souped-up cars,
their subwoofers
booming out a
hopeful techno beat

Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
I know why I'm a
bachelor; it's
because I got
disheartened and
slung in the towel.
Gus would have been
tied up years ago,
only for the girls.
Every time he gets
the lemon he tries
to put up a bluff,
that his crash is
according to
programme, but he
can't fool me.

Source: No 8 Wire: The Best of Kiwi Ingenuity
Author: BRIDGES & DOWNS
Quote:
They reversed the
name to 'Lemon &
Paeroa' and it has
continued to sell
until today.

Lemon and Paeroa
became sponsors for
those who would wear
the Fern; men made
sausage rolls for
aftergame functions
in a hundred junior
clubrooms throughout
the land.

While he was doing
this I'd scoot out
to the garage for
the L&P.

You know you are in
Ohakune when you see
the giant carrot.
The big bottle of
Lemon & Paeroa tells
you that you have
arrived in the town
of Lemon.

If the smell of
manuka twigs makes a
New Zealand boy glad
to be home, so does
a taste of L&P.

Clearly someone
needs to post a
guard on that big
carrot and the giant
Lemon & Paeroa
bottle.

We're wandering up
the main street in a
small country town
90 minutes' drive
from Auckland
Paeroa, home to a
famous fizzy drink
and, in case you
hadn't made the
connection, proud
owner of the world's
largest Lemon &
Paeroa bottle -
defiantly kitsch by
the side of the
road. Lemon & Paeroa
is the last thing on
anybody's mind this
morning.

Mock cream and lemon
cheese are about 50%
sugar.

Lemon Honey (or
lemon curd)
somehowcaptures the
essential
"sunniness" oflemons

Or, for that matter,
what's the
difference between
lemon curd, lemon
butter or lemon
honey? For most
people, the terms
are
interchangeable...

Lemon Jelly... Made
with Tauranga
lemonsthis was
delicious.

Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Quote:
These much
sought-after but
relatively rare
flatfish [flounder
and sole] are
generally found on
sandy bottoms of
shallow inshore
areas. There are
eight commercial
species in New
Zealand : the sand
flounder,
yellowbelly
flounder, greenback
flounder, black
flounder, lemon
sole, common sole,
brill and turbot.

Author: SORENSON
Quote: SOLE, ENGLISH and SOLE, LEMON (a) Scientific name: (i) Peltorhamphus novaezealandiae (ii) Pelotretus flavilatus . (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) English Sole (ii) Lemon Sole. (c) Other common names: None applicable. (d) Principal localities where taken: [south of Gisborne]

Author: WILSON
Quote:
SOLE, LEMON Unlike
Common Sole the
Lemon Sole has no
rostral flap, which
in the Common Sole
conceals the mouth
when viewed from the
right side of the
head. Colour varies,
but usually has a
distinct yellowish
tinge on the upper
surfaces which have
a camouflaged
appearance.

Of the remaining species with two pelvic fish, the Lemon Sole (Pelotretis flavilatus ) has a normal snout like the Flounder, and a broadly mottled upper surface, with lemon underside. The others have a rounded anterior end caused by an overgrowth of the snout which in the sole (Plate II. fig. 4), often but quite wrongly called the `English' Sole, entirely conceals the mouth from above, while in the last two to be mentioned the mouth is still visible from above.
Notes: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 202

Quote: Of the remaining species with two pelvic fish, the Lemon Sole (Pelotretis flavilatus ) has a normal snout like the Flounder, and a broadly mottled upper surface, with lemon underside. The others have a rounded anterior end caused by an overgrowth of the snout which in the sole (Plate II. fig. 4), often but quite wrongly called the `English' Sole, entirely conceals the mouth from above, while in the last two to be mentioned the mouth is still visible from above.
Notes: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 202

Author: MORRIS
Quote: In England, the name is applied to an inferior species of sole . In New South Wales, it is given to Plagusia unicolor , Macl., of the family Pleuronectidae or Flat-fishes. In New Zealand, it is another name for the New Zealand Turbot (q.v.).

Author: DRUMMOND & HUTTON
Quote:
The lemon sole and
the common sole,
however, have two,
and the latter has a
rounded snout.

The Lemon Sole (Ammotretis rostratus). This fish is popularly known as the lemon sole, to distinguish it from Peltorhamphus novae-zealandiae, Gunther, which the local fishermen call the English sole. The names are somewhat unfortunate, seeing that they are applied to totally different species in Britain.
Ammotretis rostratus , Gunther. Locally known as the `lemon sole'.
Lemon Sole - Ammotretis rostratus, Peltotretis flavilatus.

AMMOTRETIS GUNTHERI Hutton. Brill. Received in Wellington from Timaru and sold as `lemon sole.' The supply is small, increasing towards the end of summer. ... Distribution: South Island and Cook Strait. ... PELOTRETIS FLAVILATUS Waite. Lemon Sole . Sold as `brill' in Wellington. Mr. Adams informs me that it is common in Dunedin markets during midsummer, when examples are secured off Otago Heads in about 15 fathoms.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Quote: Pelotretis flavilatus Waite. A common species, usually known as `lemon sole'.

it is the

hat.

squeezers, high

Author: WILSON
Quote:
It looked like a
lost soldier's hat.

squeezer made of

Author: PUGSLEY
Quote:
Malone's Wellington
Battalion wore their
brimmed felt hats
with four
distinctive dents,
laterknown as the
`Lemon Squeezer'.
Malone instituted
this headdress in
his Territorial
Battalion, the 11th
Taranaki Rifles, and
on his appointment
to command the
Wellington Battalion
of the NZEF made
this the headdress
in the battalion. In
1916 this was
adopted by the New
Zealand Division. It
is still worn in the
NZ Army on
ceremonial
occasions.

lemon-squeezer ...
peaked hat
(formerly) worn by
NZ and Australian
soldiers.
Notes: nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 282

Quote:

with lemon
squeezers. Weren't

Quote:

lemon-squeezer ...

Quote:

boys in lemon
squeezers and
pretend we're

Quote:
lemon-squeezer:

Author: McLEAN

Author: McARA
Quote: The first axial-water-feed hammer-drills were available about 1910. Leyner drills of this type were by then widely used in tunnels in the United States. They represented a great advance over the piston-type drills and besides proving more efficient reduced the dust problem underground. The Leyners were followed by other makes, notably Holman's, but the name persisted and the common name for the `big machine' or drifter at Waihi remained the `liner'. These drills were worked in a steel cradle about four-and-a-half-feet long, mounted on a feed-screw with a short handle at the rear ... Ibid. 326 Leyner water-feed-drill: The first axial-water-feed-drill used at Waihi. By controlling dust it marked the virtual end of the terrible scourage of phthisis, though many who already had the disease continued to die every year for some considerable time

Author: NEWTON
Quote: Such was that dog's way with sheep that when running out - say on the right - he could make his lift from round about three o'clock and yet turn his sheep directly towards me. I have, of course, often heard the argument that the run-out cannot be judged until the dog has lifted his sheep. In other words, provided the sheep turn directly towards the man when `lifted', the dog has finished his head correctly regardless of whether it is short or otherwise. Ibid. 168 (Glossary) Lift: When a dog has completed his head his next job is quietly to start them on the `pull'. This, the first movement in the pull, is known as the lift. To pull is to bring the sheep back to the man.

Lift: Action of a
dog to move sheep
from a standing
position.

Lifters comprise a

that is screwed
underneath the
winter comb, raising
it by 2.5 cm.
Lifters are
replacing blades in
some areas.

The use of winter
combs with attached
'lifters' is
becoming more common
in colder regions.

Author: ANGAS
Quote:
The body is enclosed
in a mausoleum of
carved woodwork
within the `pah' for
several months, and
at the expiration of
this period, the
ceremony of `lifting
the bones' takes
place, which is
performed by the
nearest relative of
the diseased. The
bones, after being
well scraped and
cleaned, are then
deposited in a box,
and buried.

Author: ACLAND
Quote:
Dagnam was very
light country and
only carried about
1000 sheep.

The country is
light, rainfall
abundant.

Author: GORDON
Quote:
Light country, it's
also drought-prone;
in other words, it's
a demanding place to
run, especially at a
substantial stocking
rate.

Author: GRADY
Quote:
[glossary] Fires, to
light - Signals to

telling them in

go to pursue whales

vantage-points. The
Peranos had a code
of signal fires.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
Tutira It was
likewise impossible
to change light
lands into good
lands.

Light land is more
quickly broken in
than a stiff heavy
soil; it is much
easier to manage at
any time, and is
usually warm and
"early". But it is
very "hungry" - that
is, it consumes
humus and other
manures quickly.

light ... 21. light

Light-mantled sooty albatross Phoebetria palpebrata A 2.75 kg albatross that breeds on high-latitude islands in the Atlantic, Indian and Pacific Oceans. It is rarely seen in coastal waters.

Visitors to the
Auckland Islands..
usually see sooty
albatrosses sitting
on their nests,
which are in clefts
in perpendicular
cliff faces, or are
on ledges some 30
feet high.

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The

As basketball in

terminology to

... The guys that

lightbulb changers,
nose bleeders and
sky walkers, and the
best of them can
turn the 360 (full
circle) or take the
alley-oop pass (ball
thrown high up by
the basket). They
can also throw the
rock (ball) down or
stuff the pill
(ball).

Quote: Lignum , n. (I), or Lignum-Viteae . The name is applied to several trees, as Myrtus acmenioides , F. v. M., called also White Myrtle; Acacia falcata , Wild., N.O. Leguminosae , called also Hickory and Sally ; but chiefly to Eucalyptus polyanthema , Schau., N.O. Myrtaceae .

Ake-ake, ( Metrosideros buxifolia .) This is a variety of the Rata, No. 10. It is often called the Lignum vitae of New Zealand, and resembles that wood in hardness, weight, and colour.

Source: New Zealand, S. Aust. and NSW
Author: JAMESON

Ibid. 177 Ake-ake[Maori name] .. Lignum vitae [Settlers' name] .. Dodonea viscosa .. Small tree

The Ake, or New Zealand Lignum Vitae, (Dodonaea viscosa,) is a small tree or large shrub ... [48] Its wood is very hard and very heavy ... It is used for Sheaves, Axe-handles, &c.

Author: MARKHAM
Quote: Pouriedee [puriri] is a fine hard wood like Lignum Vitae, grows into immense trees, but you can not planks out of it as the Worms ... make places like Nail holes ....
... one in particular whose wood is almost as hard as Lignum Vitae and as beautiful as Cedar. [fn 2] Hardness suggests first the Southern Rata ..., Metrosideros umbellata... [or] Matai .

The Blue play like

everybody calls for

Then for one month

From a journalist's

All this has totally

running around like

and alternative

The Nats are running

The Poatini [Poutini] (West Coast) natives arrived. Feasted them on Lilipee. Ibid. 1854 Apr 25 8/171 Several large canoes were filled with what they [at Poarikaino] called Riripi, i.e. flour and water boiled and sweetened with sugar.

Source: Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson
Author: HAAST
Quote: ... I found that [our provisions] would only last us ten days by confining ourselves to a small pot of lillipe (or boiled flour) twice a day, with the hoped-for addition of wekas or eels... Ibid. 38 After a hearty meal of lilipi our other provisions being exhausted....

Source: Crusts: a settler's fare due south
Author: KENNAWAY
Quote:
The poor children,
who lived
principally on heavy
bread and
`lillippee' (its) (a
mixture containing
nothing more nor
less than
paper-hanging paste)
cried at intervals
...

To this [Maori
c1855] feast I
received a special
invitation, and ...
I accepted it,
especially as the
fare was to consist
of Lipi, dried shark
and potatoes. Upon
arriving at the Pah
I found the `Lipi'
mixed in a canoe. It
consisted of flour,
sugar, and water.
The men were sitting
round, helping
themselves by means
of pannikins, mussel
shells, and their
hands.

[The Maoris] were
also [fond] of wheat
and sugar boiled
together, to which
they gave the name
of `Lilipa'.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
The most important
dish ... was a kind
of gruel made out of
flour, sugar, and
water, mixed in a
canoe, and called
lilipi.

Author: VON HAAST
Quote:
Haast having
inspected the
provisions found
they would last ...
by reducing his
party to a small pot
of lillipi (boiled
flour) twice a day,
with a hoped-for
addition of wekas or
eels.

Author: BOSWELL
Quote:
She made what we
called `lillipy', a
corruption of the
Maori rerepe, a dish
made by boiling the
pollen of the raupo
in water to a
porridge. Mother's
`lillipy' was made
by stirring plain
flour into boiling
milk to a thick
porridge, when it
was poured out on to
a huge meat plate
and dotted and
dabbed with butter
and sugar, with a
good sprinkling of
nutmeg. It also was
a fine lunch on a
cold day.

Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Quote:
'...[sic] twenty
pots of stirabout'.
(Stirabout,
otherwise known as
lillipee, consisted
simply of flour and
sugar mixed together
with a little a
boiled water.)
[`part from Marianne
Williams's journal]

One day the native
cooks opened the bag
of lime, thinking it
was flour, and
proceeded to mix it
with water and
sugar, in order to
provide "stirabout"
or "lillipee," dear
to the palate of the
Maori.

Quote:
Lillipee feasting...
So much lillipee (a

canoe was cleaned
out and used as the

Mr Punch will
recommend that the

Master N.-d, when

Eng...d's

They have argued
that land
information
memorandum (LIM)
reports have to flag
the possible
contamination ...

LIM reports, one of
the key protections
for house buyers
trying to avoid
buying "lemons", are

many people believe,
an investigation
shows... LIMs are
intended to provide
certain basic
information about a

code, is prone to

When the owner..

Information
Memorandum (LIM)

complied but a
council officer
later admitted he
had not done a
thorough
inspection... When
we do a LIM report
we ensure our
inspectors chase
everything up.

Farmers, he says,
don't think about
Lim (Land
Information
Memorandum) reports
if there is no
housing involved.

It paid to get a
Land Information
Memorandum (LIM)
from the council to
indicate what
restrictions might
be placed on
development.

A LIM report is [a]
handy tool for
property hunters. A
Land Information
Memorandum (LIM)
provides information
held by the local
authority on a
property... A LIM
report might include
information about
potential erosion,
contamination or
flooding; structural
requirements; where
the street water
pipes and sewerage
run; rates details;
consents and notices
that have been
issued relating to
this or neighbouring
properties; the
zoning that says
what can be done
with the land;
likely future use
such as new roads;
information from
other utility
providers; and any
other information
the local authority
regards as relevant.

I'm still amazed at
the number of people
who buy houses
without independent
builder's
assessments, LIM
reports or
engineer's surveys.

A Land Information
Memorandum (LIM)..
gives information on
land and buildings
as they exist, and
it can be applied
for at any time
without the need for
a building consent.

country, or, as he

had not got the
lime-juice out of me
yet;' so it can't be
colonial slang that
I speak.' Well, I
don't know that
colonials are worse
than other people
for speaking slang,
but they have, of
course, many words
and phrases peculiar
to themselves.'

Author: DAVIDSON
Quote:
Jim had a mate ...
who looked with
contempt upon my
brother as being
quite a new chum,
and savouring
strongly of lime
juice.

Author: TREGEAR
Quote:
I see that you are a
new arrival and if
you will kindly
stand on one side
(for the smell of
limejuice is
unpleasant) I will
tell you.
lime-juicer n.

... the little
lime-juicer ...

It has been
estimated that Te
Kuiti limestones,
including those in
the Waitomo area,
are 50 to 80 per
cent bryozoan
remains, and Oamaru
stone 70 per cent.

Other recent
evidence that the
Maori tribal
collectivist model
is a failure [to]
include the high
proportion of Maori
living in
towns/districts that
the Goverment's
jobs-jolt agenda has
singled out as
providing
insufficient jobs
for the unemployed
to realistically
expect to be able to
find work. People
can no longer move
to these "limited
employment
locations" and
expect to get the
dole.

Author: SMITH
Quote:
The `Limited' is the
train which runs
daily between
Wellington and
Auckland (and vice
versa). It leaves
Wellington at 7.10
p.m. ...

`You can put Mac on
with Monty', I told
Dawson, `and young
Jimmy can spell
Arthur.' I wasn't
going to stand there
arguing ... and I
wanted a ride fifty
miles to the
township to get the
Limited ...

New Zealand has
developed many
phrases that depend
on local
interpretation: e.g.
`The Limited', `the
six oclock rush',
`off the bitumen',
`motor camp', `to
farewell', `to
pencil in', `to
check up on',
`return (at meals)'.
All these are
immediately
understandable to
New Zealanders, but
not always to
others.

We pulled up to let
both the three
o'clock express to
Auckland, and the
seven-fifteen
`Limited', pass us.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
The train that was
carrying me south
from Auckland into
the night bore an
exciting title - the
Limited.

The decision to run
the "limited" at
night has been
arrived at after
very careful
consideration.

The introduction of
the Limited train
between Auckland and
Wellington made an
immediate appeal to
the popular
imagination... The
introduction of a
summer running
train, which took
advantage of the
daylight, was also
'limited in its
accommodation'... It
brought about a
desire for more
specific titles, so
"Daylight Limited"
and "Night Limited"
became the terms
commonly used in
referring to them.

... you were drawn
beneath the wheels
of a train if you
stood too near the
edge of the
platform. That was
the terrible danger
when the Limited
came rushing in ...

Author: JOHNSON
Quote:
.. with second-class
tickets and a pillow
each we boarded the
Limited at seven on
the evening for the
northern terminus

Source: Book of New Zealand, A (J.C. Reid)
Quote:

on as fireman on the

she'd be jake but
now it's just a
flaming mess;

Author: WILSON
Quote:

up and went off on
the Limited express

at ten o'clock.

You wouldn't expect
the 7.50 from

Author: IRELAND

Many is the time I
would wake up in the

itch to be moving

In the heyday of

carried 250 to 300
passengers a night.

Limpets, Cellana spp. The `very beautiful sea Ears' were certainly the Paua, Haliotis iris ; ...

Author: M'DONNELL

The rivers are well
stocked with fine
fish ... - the very

them. There are
abundance of
lobsters, crawfish,
oysters, prawns, and

Author: POLACK
Quote: fn Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called para [as-acute] paraua [a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, mungu nui (black physeter); right whale, tohora (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, mango (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

It was a tiny
freshwater limpet.
Moving the stones
caused it to release
luminous mucus - a
defence mechanism
against predators
such as eels. The
glowing goo is
carried away by the
current and diverts
the predator's
attention. Found
only in the North
Island, the limpet
is one of the very
few bioluminescent
animals in the
world.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
In the nineteenth
century the ring
game seems to have
been the most
popular marble game.
(In more recent
years marble games
with holes have had
the greater role.)
There was Big Ring,
in which a circle a
yard or more in
diameter was drawn
on the ground; there
was the mullibar
variation, in which
an outsize taw was
catapulted amongst
the marbles in this
circle. There were
Little Ring, Liney,
Follows, Follow the
Taw, Holey, and
then, on a less
important scale,
Butcher's Board, in
which the marbles
were bowled through
the holes in a
board,
Eye-Drop,Knock-Backs,
Leggings-Out (or
Leggin's-Out),
Span-'Em, and
Backits. The last
was more usually a
girls' game.

Author: KEITH & MAIN
Quote:

various games -

and, seen here,
`ringey' - which
could be played for
`funs' or `keeps.'

An offshore species

sharp-toothed
southern kingfish,
ugly green monkfish
and slimy flathead,
electric skates and

toothed snouts.

Author: PARROTT
Quote: The Ling was known to the Maoris as Hokarari. Some years ago large catches were made in Cloudy Bay, and were placed on the Wellington market as `Cloudy Bay Cod'. The scientific name Genypterus blacodes , freely translated, means `a flabby fish, with a fin on the chin.' The New Zealand Ling is also found in Australia where it is known as the `Rockling.'

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Ling n. a fish. The name is given in England to various fishes, from their length. In New Zealand and Tasmania, it is applied to Genypterus blacodes, Forst.; also called Cloudy Bay Cod. Author: HOCKEN

It was at this time
[c1851], that the
smart and
appropriate
sobriquet of the
`Little Enemy' was
affixed to a small
but obstructive body
of gentlemen in the
community, mostly of
standing and
intelligence, and
supporters of Sir
George Grey. English
and Episcopalian,
they were viewed as
intruders ... and
reciprocated by
seeing in the
special scheme of
the settlement and
its leaders all that
was narrow and
intolerant. In a
superior way they
stood aloof from the
rest, and their
attitude was one of
opposition. ... No
quarter was given,
no consideration
shown on either
side. The advent of
the beneficent
constitution finally
ended these
bickerings ... and
though the term
`Little Enemy' clung
long, it was rather
as a memory than a
badge.

board, Eye-Drop, ...

Quote: LITTLE SHAG Phalacrocorax melanoleucos brevirostris Maori name: Kawaupaka. The name White-throated Shag is also in general use for the most abundant phase of a rather variable species which, at its other extreme, is identical with the Little Pied Shag of Australia. However, as intermediates occur, and the Little Pied form is relatively uncommon, it seems more convenient to treat the New Zealand population as a variable one under a distinctive name.

In response to Felicity Monk's story ("Does my bum look naked in this?"),.. on "lo ryders", as she calls them, I was disgusted at the way she portrayed people who have enough confidence to wear clothes in a way that they want and not to worry about what others think.

Girls are wearing their pants low. Very low. They're called - well, of course they are - lo ryders and, if they rode any lower, barbershops could be in for a roaring trade. Ibid. 31 Lo ryders are about as practical as a pair of MC Hammer pants on a sprinter. If you have ever watched a lo ryder wearer attempt to manoeuvre herself into a seated position, you will know.

Author: LELAND
Quote: bread: It comes in standard-sized loaves (government regulation). 350g (about 12 oz), 500g (about 1 lb), 700g (about 1 and a half lb). Unfortunately, common parlance for these loaves differs between the North and South islands. Many of the 700g loaves are made like a camel with two so that they can conveniently be split in half. Usually, if you ask for a loaf in the South Island it is one of these two humps (350g) that you get. In the North Island, if you want the same amount of bread (350g) you must ask for a half loaf. The other thing about bread, is that in this land of abundant food, where restaurant servings are usually generous, it is very hard to get more than one piece of bread (or one roll). Unlike North America, where they seem to hope you will settle for smaller servings if you fill up with bread, in New Zealand restaurants appear afraid that you will spoil your appetite with the stuff.

The rivers are well

In order to ascertain the possibilities of lobsters [European lobster, Homarus vulgaris ] and crayfish living peaceably together, one of each, both accustomed to confinement, were placed in an observation-tank. But there can be no question as to the lobster being `boss,' as it chased the crayfish about the tank, snapping at it with its powerful claws, the crayfish having to ascend to the surface to get out of its way, so that they had to be at once separated.

wheels suitable for
wooden rails, and
the engine from an
old Ford 100E was at
hand. It took 2 [and
a half] days to
build, and with half
a 44-gallon drum as
a bonnet and a coast
of green paint, was
soon looking a
picture. An old
four-wheel railway
trolley coupled on
behind completed
therolling stock

Author: BEARDSLEY
Quote: lokey locomotive

Whilst working for
Smyth Bros & Boryer,
Arohena, 1942 to
1945, then Ngaroma
1945 to 1956, the
Lockie was turned
around with the
smoke box facing the

It debased the
budget in the place
where it ought to
matter most and
underlined the
growing importance
of the late 80s
phenomenon called
the lock-up.
Lock-ups are
sealed-room
briefings for
journalists and
analysts two nor
three hours before
the budget
presentation... The
opposition is locked
out of the lock-up,
and the government's
own backbenchers get
only a cursory
briefing just before
the budget's
delivered.

If only the Greens
had staged their
silent protest a day
later. The press
gallery and a
phalanx of analysts
and technicians
could have been
saved the boredom of
the budget lock-up
to concentrate on
the only issue on
political minds -
the election date
and anything that
may precipitate it.
But no, Thursday's
lock-up went, as it
always does, without
a hitch.

[The government]
assembled a
Budget-sized mob of
officials and held a
lock-up. This is a
thing whereby
journalists and
hangers-on are
detained for a
couple of hours
under guard, minus
cellphones - burly
security escorts to
and from the toilet,
the works - while
they are briefed
about the documents.
The ideas being, if
let loose too soon,
they might derange
the Dow Jones with
half-cocked ideas of
the government's
brilliant blueprint
for worl domination.

It's tradition that the guys and gals from the money markets and the scribes from the parliamentary press gallery get an advance peek at the budget in special "lock-ups" held before the finance minister reads the document in the House.

Without the injured
[player], coach John
Bracewell was trying
to develop a
"locker" of four
options at the
death...

Source: NZ Woman's Weekly: The First 60 Years

or panel beater (car
body mechanic).

Author: FITTON
Quote:
NEW ZEALAND. -
Scoured fleece, 1s.
8-1/2d. ...; average

unwashed, 10-1/2d.
...

... the latter is

Author: McDONALD

about 7ft. x 5ft.,

... to permit the
locks or second cuts
to fall through.

Author: McDONALD
Quote: The big stations may make classing a very simple business, ... and may even divide up the skirtings or pieces from the fleece into different classes, besides keeping the bellies, locks, and stained wool separate. Ibid. 148 The belly wool and the pieces or locks are kept separate from the fleece when rolling it, ...

Author: SMITH
Quote:
There are also
baskets for the
bellies and locks

is the name given to
the young man or boy
whose duty it is to
[75] carry the wool
from the shearer to
the skirting table
...

`Locks' consist
mainly of short
pieces of wool such
as second cuts,
sweepings and short
wool that falls on
to the table during
handling.

Boards which fit
between cleats on
opposite legs of the
[wool] table keep
the locks from being
trampled on.

`What's 2nd Pcs H?'
`Grade 2, pieces -

`Oh, that's floor
sweepings.' `What

Locks: Short wool
which has either
fallen through the
wool table or been

Locks see skirtings. Ibid. 17 ... colonial woolscourers who removed grease, sticks and thistles from the locks and pieces - the dirty, inferior quality skirtings trimmed from the fleeces.

lock ... (in pl.) NZ
& Austral. small
pieces of wool that
fall off fleece
during shearing.

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote:
Fleece. The main
part of the sheep's
wool when shorn. It
is picked up in one
piece and carried to
the wool table,
where it is skirted
and classed. The
small bits and
pieces that are cut
off separately by
the shearer are the
locks, bellies and
pieces.

On a dark wet night

The members who came

private sector jobs
are still getting

Parliament's squalid
offices, either in
the bowels of the
old building or in
Siberia, the
tacked-on Lockwood
annex out the back.

Exiled from Siberia,
the Lockwood
addition to
parliament
Buildings, defeated
... MP Reg Boorman
was a poignant sight
this week as he
cleared his office.

Quest.: Why do dykes
like living in
Lockwoods [Lockwood
homes]? Response:
Because there are no
studs and lots of
[all] tongue and
groove.

The big, sanitised
Lockwood huts of the
national parks have
never looked
comfortable in their
surroundings. They
are designed to hold
and shift large
numbers of people
and do so
marvellously well,
but they are
characterless.

Lodgepole pine,
Pinus contorta, is a
relative of the
familiar radiata
pine.

Lodgepole pine, Pinus contorta, is a relative of the familiar radiata pine... In the south-eastern Kaweka Ranges contorta has marched across the southern ridges, shading out many species, and in places is so thick that pushing through it has become virtually impossible. Each year, the Department of Conservation tackles areas of contorta for removal, but it is an ongoing and expensive battle. In the eastern South Island ,there is no control, and contorta threatens to change tussockland into exotic forests.

Source: Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The
Author: MAHONEY
Quote: The biggest tram... was operated from 1904 to 1944 by the Taupo Totara Timber Company and required a fleet of six lokeys. Ibid. 79 The word 'lokey' is bushman's slang for a steam locomotive used on a bush tramway. From interviews with several hundred old bushmen it is apparent that the term was widely used throughout the ountry. Ibid. 83 New Zealand made an early start in introducing lokeys to bush tramways from the 1870s onwards, but an economic depression considerably slowed the process.

[Hdg] Sex, Lies &
Lolly Shops... On
February 10, 1916,

Disease and Dreadful
Truth' about the so
called 'lolly shops'
in Cambridge Tce

to operate from
brothels providing
they didn't employ
anyone else...

[Title] Lolly shops 'of the red-light kind' and 'soldiers of the King'. Suppressing one-woman brothels in New Zealand, 1908-1916. Ibid. 15 Truth, in its usual melodramatic style of making sex news, reported evocatively of one-woman brothels: 'the confectionery bagnio . . . "lollie shops" in Cambridge-terrace [which] are houses of crimson vice'. In its 'Warning to Warriors when in Wellington,' it describes in meticulous detail a lolly shop, 'one of the "red light" kind', which, the tabloid claimed, would receive as many as 40 clients of an evening, all 'soldiers of the King.'

In winter, when many
farms were short of
grass, it was common
practice for stock
to be turned out on
to the roadside
verges or the 'long
acre' as it was
called.

The only spat I can
ever remember was
over grazing the
'long acre' or
roadside in a severe
drought.

The 'long acre'
often comes to the
rescue of many stock
during winter as
bonus feed which has
all been eaten out
on the block.

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush

settling into his

Author: BOWEN
Quote: As long as you get to the flank, you are all right, for when you come to the long blow, with the sheep laid out correctly - you can get the flank quite easily at that time - at the start of the long blow. Ibid. 30 ... the shearer still has a long awkward long blow, almost from the tail to the head, and tends to make more second cuts than with the new style.

(H.A.L. Laing) Long
blow: The shearing
strokes, usually
five in number,
along the sheep's
back as it lies on
the board. After
completing the long
blow the shearer
moves on to the
`last side'.

LONG BLOW: The
shearing strokes,
usually five in
number, along the
sheep's back as it
lies on the board.
`The finest blow in
shearing'.

Author: NEWTON

Laying his sheep
full length he swung
into the 'long blow'
from rump to neck.

lie her out for the
long blows.

Author: JOHNSTON
Quote:
`Dunny box for a new
long drop,' Hec
grunted and
continued with his
work.

The toilet was a
`long drop' in a
little tin hut down
the gardenpath, near
the woodshed

And at the river
plateau settlement
of Te Waiti where
big blowflies
dive-bomb the long
drops, 150 invited
guests clutched cans
.

He stressed the dark
side of the national
force: macrocarpas,
child molestation,
murder in the long
drop.

Various things were
used to mark off the
whole complex from
the wild or from the
next bach - the
water-tank, the
long-drop, the
smokehouse, the
outside fireplace...

Our little climbing
community dug a long
drop and mowed lawns
in exchange for tent
space.

Their [sc. Greenie
frumps'] greatest
pleasure should be
long tramps into the
bush on cold, wet
days to worship
mauka, and doing
maypole dances
around long drops.

We have philosophy
and higher
mathematics, and
hip-hop, and the
motor car. We did
not invent these
things so that we
would need, ever
again, to experience
the long drop, and
its close and
equally stinky
relation, the
chemical loo.

It has to do with a
small path which led
to the long-drop
(the long-drop
itself is best
forgotten, something
easier said than
done).

Still, on this day
in 1901, Annie
Taylor wedged
herself inside a
wooden keg and set
off over Niagara
Falls to become the
first person to ride
the proverbial
long-drop.

My Piha is focussed
on a humble little
one-room fibrolite
bach with a longdrop
in the bush at the
back.

There's only a
makeshift shower
(usually just for
the kids) out the
back and a long drop
for a toilet. You
get used to the
blowflies.

"Deep, like a long
drop ... Not this
time, Davy boy."

House and telephone
are solar-powered, a
spring gives water,
a composting toilet
replaces the ruined
longdrop beneath a
huge totara.

The toilets were of
the long-drop type,
with sprung seats.
They were only to be
used while the train
was in motion.

We managed to
convince [my younger
brother] that the
long drop was the
hideout for a
particularly
ferocious possum
whose greatest joy
in life was
attacking the nether
regions of those
using it.

One job she didn't
do, a pleasure that
awaited my father on
his next visit, was
cleaning the
longdrop.

[My body] loathes
uncertainty, sudden
change or
long-drops.

The ablution
department is
rudimentary and open
to the sky, the
marine equivalent of
the Kiwi longdrop,
but entirely private
and adequate.

Ms Sunderland said
[the documentary]
was still being
researched but even
at this early stage
she could confirm
that "the long drop
was well and truly
still alive in New
Zealand."

A long drop was a
dwelling where the
great outdoors
merged with the
great indoors and
caused the person
occupying it to
meditate not only on
the marvels of
nature but also on
the marvels of
modern sanitation.

Welcome to our home
and garden edition.
Well, to be precise,
our shack and
longdrop edition.

It looks at the
famous Kawakawa
toilets, the
longdrop, waterless
urinals in cinemas,
Portaloos, aircraft
toilets, the Twyford
urinal in
Parliament.

Author: GEE
Quote:
She also needed to
use the longdrop.

Author: DUDER
Quote:
The toilet was a
long drop in a
tinyouthouse twenty
yards away.

If you hate it,
that's probably
because you're not
keen on lack of
ensuite facilities
(which, in camping
terms, generally
means squatting
behind a bush or
trekking to a long
drop), creaky camp
stretchers or the
abundance of
creepy-crawlies that
wriggle into your
nightie.

It was a happy day when I got the boot from that job and I took it as a compliment but I have always had a residual soft spot for the [Reader's Digest]Laughter is the Best Medicine section when I've since come across it in bach long drops.

Source: At the End of Darwin Road
Author: Fiona Kidman
Quote:
The long drop dunny,
instead of being
across the paddock,
was in the back yard
...

Source: Good Bastards: the larrikin's guide to success
Quote:
My copy had also
arrived the day
before, and had just
been jettisoned down
the long drop dunny,
as did all things
which looked like
official mail from
the Correspondence
school Clifton
Terrace Wellington.

I was pleased right
away, because the
long drop dunny,
instead of being out
of sight of the
house as at our last
place, was in the
backyard, separated
only by a spreading
plum tree from the
living quarters. It
became a favourite
place for my father
to read. Notes

But most of all
those baches meant
the horror of the
long-drop toilet, a
memory that's
mysteriously glossed
over in romantic
evocations of summer
holidays in the
nicest literature.

...there hasn't been
a place that
defeated that
principle, although
there have been some
interesting ones -
including a
house-truck and a
one-room Waiheke
bach with a
long-drop toilet.

From previous
encouters with the
long drop toilet I
knew that an out
house filled with
spiders, cobwebs and
even the odd weta
was part of the Kiwi
experience.

In those days a tent
site with cold water
laid on and
long-drop toilets
cost half a crown
per week (25 cents).

Quote:
I went on to Kaiapoi
by the side road

scattered farming
district, and there

this journey, cows
grazing in `the long
paddock'.

The spotlight has
been trained once
again on to the
`long paddock', that
vexed question
thatliberal-minded,
trail-blazing
surveyors passed on
to posterity. Their
bequest made
provision for a
five-figure mileage
of main roads and a
chain-wide vastness
in secondary roads
longer than the
distance from New
Zealand to Europe
and back again. The
purpose of this
article is not to
take liberties with
statistics, for
nobody has measured
accurately the
potential that the
Hawke's Bay County
Council spoke of in
its recent decision
to press for action
on the shameful
wastageperpetuated
by the sanctity of
the long paddock.

long paddock n. the

graze on roadside.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
There are five
standard classes [in
dog trialling], each
incorporating three
events. The standard
classes are as
follows: Class I
(the Long Pull);
Class II (the Drive
and Yard); Class IIA
(a SouthIsland
event); Class III
(the Zig-zag or
Slew) and Class IV
(The Straight Hunt.)
The three events in
each class are: The
maiden, for dogs
which have not won a
maiden event; the
Intermediate, open
only to dogs which
have won a maiden
but have not won an
open; and lastly,
the open itself. The
standard events are
usually held on hill
courses.

More especially in
the "long pull" have
the prizes been
increased.

Last year's
programme with
slight alterations
was adopted, the
principal difference
being the
lengthening of the
"long pull" from 680
yards to about half
a mile, and Class
IV. youths to be
over 18, and their
task to be same as
Class II. yarding
omitted and sheep to
be taken off the
course to the
satisfaction of the
judge.

.. in 1981 Bob
Bariss sold his
heading bitch Pearl
to Alan Dever, just
after Pearl and Bob
came second in the
New Zealand long
pull.

The other eye
grabber was what
they call in the
south the long pull
and in the north the
long head.

Author: HALL
Quote:
The long pull is
where a shepherd
stands in a ring
marked with stones,
about ten paces in
radius, and brings
the sheep down the
hill to him; it
finishes when the
shepherd, the dog
and the sheep are
all perfectly
stationary for at
least a second.

We achieved a
complete in the long
pull.

Source: High Times in the High Country

Author: [WICKHAM]
Quote:
He just took a "long
sleeve" of his own
beer to cool his
choler.

Gus Coates, seeing
the bottom of
another long
sleever, declared
the next time he
went fishing, he
would take with him
luckier mates than
Geordie Grey, Johnny
Hall, and Stubbing.

Entering into
conversation with an
engaging young lady
behind the bar, he
ordered a long
sleever, and over it
he asked, "How do
you get on with the
boss?"

Many and varied are
the shrieks that
howl round this
sublunary sphere,
the cold-blooded
shriek of baffled
villainy; the shriek
of the fond and
foolish mother over
the buttonless
garments of her
hopeful
seven-year-old; the
shriek of the
impecunious toper
who cannot run "a
long sleever"; the
subdued yet audible
shriek of the
defeated candidate
for parliamentary
honors, and the
subdued shriek of
the canvassers for
the said candidate
who won't be paid
...

Boss, gimme a long
sleever.

Next followed the
two long sleevers of
Marshall & Copeland,
and again almost in
the sounding of the
trump, or the
twinkling of an eye
"nothing remained."

He said Braslin
helped him to search
for the missing man,
whose name was
McCartney, and
stated he had simply
given the latter a
hand to carry the
tubers, his reward
being a long
sleever.

work.

Analysis of data
from a recorder at
Timaru has revealed
six "long wave"
events, with the
largest on April 4,
2002, peaking at 1.2
metres.

Port's long waves to
be monitored .. The
Hawke's Bay Regional
Council installed
the recorder as part
of a study by the
National Institute
of Water and
Atmospheric Research
into long waves that
turn up on the East
Coast. .. Scientist
Derek Goring said
the long waves,
which came at
intervals of seven
to 11 minutes, were
the bane of port
operators and ship
owners at open coast
ports such as
Napier, Gisborne,
Timaru and, to a
lesser extent,
Lyttelton. ..
Scientists want to
know why, and how
often, long waves
turned up, so they
could provide
more-informed
warning procedures.
.. While a lot of
work had still to be
done, he hoped the
research would allow
NIWA to predict when
the long waves would
occur.

Quote: There are two species of freshwater eels in New Zealand, one. the short-finned Anguilla australis schmidtii ... having the dorsal fin about the same length as the ventral fin, and the other. A. dieffenbachii ... , having the dorsal fin continuing well forward of the point where the ventral fin stops. The long-fin is usually predominant in cold water, ...

Author: PAUL
Quote: Longfinned eel Anguilla dieffenbachii ... Alternatively, longfin. Occurs throughout New Zealand, but not elsewhere.

The short--finned eel (Anguilla australis) is found in New Zealand and south-east Australia, while the similar long-finned eel (Anguilla dieffenbachia) is found only in this country. [43] A good supply of wild eels, both the short-finned and the long-finned types, has long been taken for granted.

Two other species ply our fresh waters - the shortfin eel (A. australis), and the Australian longfin (A. reinhardtii), a recent arrival currently restricted to the northern part of the North Island. Of the three the New Zealand longfin ins the most impressive. Described by those who have seen them a "logs that moved", there have been confirmed sightings of specimens up to two metres in length ...

Both our varieties
of eel - the short
finned and the long
finned - are good to
eat. There's a
slight variation in
the colour of the
flesh (pinkish in
the case of the
long-finned, greyish
in the case of the
short) but it takes
an expert to tell
the difference
between the two.

New Zealand longfin
eels, among the
largest freshwater
eels on Earth, breed
just once and may
live for more than
90 years. They spend
most of their lives
in fresh water
before making a 6000
km journey across
the Pacific ocean,
to a particular site
thought to be near
Tonga, where they
breed and die.

Local Maori called
the long fin eel
kuwharuwharu, and
the short fin eel
tuna hao or tuna
heke.

The system of work
[in the Grey
coalfield] is mainly
by bord and pillar,
a small portion only

are worked back. The
roof has in [418]
main proved good,
enabling a large
percentage of the
pillar-coal to be
won.

Soup.

(Griffiths

An islander has told

`The name was coined

Author: LELAND
Quote:
loopies: In the
resort areas of New
Zealand
(particularly
Central Otago), the
residents and
transient workers
have a name for
those of us who only
come to sun, ski,
climb or boat. I
haven't been able to
find the origin of
this ungenerous
appellation for
tourists and I'm not
sure I want to.

Loopies: the local
[Golden Bay] word
for tourists. I
didn't understand
it, but maybe, as
ourtail-lights
ascended, the locals
were in the
settlements below,
pointing: There
child, that red fire
fly light on the
mountain, there go
the loopies.

In the same Listener
Aucklander Geoff
Chapple, last heard
of hiding behind a
bush off the Heaphy
Track, wondered why
the South Island
word for tourists is
`loopies'. (At first
he thought it was
`loonies'.) We
thought it must have
come from `loopy',
meaning wrong in the
head, but sources in
the southern
heartland assure us
that the term almost
certainly
derivesfrom
tourists' propensity
for taking the loop
road in any given
area, with the
general idea of
seeing more of the
countryside. How
diverting.

Loopies [headline]
While leafing
through the Listener
of June 16 I came
across the headline
`Look, child, there
go the loopies'. I
quickly scanned the
article to see if
`loopy' meant what I
thought it did. ...
One of the words
used by Mr Chapman
was `loup', from the
Norse `hlaupa'
meaning `leap'.
Orkney residents
would describe
tourists as
`loupers', meaning
`leapers',
presumably because
they jumped from
place to place.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
loopies tourists;
dismissive term by
locals, possibly
because tourists do
a quick loop and
off.

Author: No.3 : 6
Quote:
LOOPIES ON ICE
[headline] Tourists
have in the past
visited Antarctica
in the comfort of

Explorer and in jet
aircraft. Few ever

Source: Under the Bridge & Over the Moon
Author: IRELAND
Quote:
Not a thing was
smarmied over or
concealed, in the
way the teaching
loopies of today
take it on
themselves to
'protect' our
children's
imaginations by
distrusting and
debasing them [sc.
Grimm's Fairy Tales]

Anyway, sand, sun,
scenery,
hair-stylists on the
beach,
rent-a-bikists,
cheap
pseudo-spirits,
Aussie one-pounder
steaks,
billion-mozzie
swimming pools - all
had been sacrificed
to "loopies" so that
Indonesia could get
on with the chore of
starving quietly to
death.

In the cities it is
relatively harmless
as the
infrastructures that
exist to service the
regular working
population are well
able to cater for a
few loopies as well.

I now looked deeply
into Heather's eyes,
trying to detect
whether she was
treating me as a
"Loopie", an
expression South
Islanders have for
outsiders - foreign
tourists, that is,
and "foreigner" down
there includes
anyone from north of
Cook Strait,
especially
Aucklanders.

I learned a new word
at Te Anau -
"Loopies." It refers
to the thousands of
tourists who in two
weeks flock to
Christchurch, cross
over to the West
Coast, "do"
Queenstown and
Fiordland, and then
return via Mt Cook.

NOTE: That the
interdepartmental
leaking roster is
now fully extended,
providing
photocopies of
government secret
documents to Labour,
Alliance, Act, New
Zealand First,
independent loopies,
trade unions,
radical charities,
journalists and
assorted nutters in
the community.

They like the way
Foveaux Strait acts
as a deterrent to
"loopies" (the local
word for tourists).

Besides, in the end,
and the loopies
notwithstanding, the
people are usually
right.

But it is Christmas
that brings the
hordes to Golden
Bay. 'Loopies', the
locals call them -
holidaymakers,
mostly from
Christchurch, who
descend like
migrating birds on
the beaches and cram
the campgrounds to
capacity.

The derogatory name
[on the Chatham
islands]for visitors
is Loopies.

The reality is that
Bluff needs a
complete facelift
and Stewart
Islanders don't
particularly like
tourists. They call
them loopies.

Quote:
The Labour Party

tenure known as

soon discovered that
it was a liability.
No one could hope to

acknowledging their
true god whose name
was Private
Property.

Ask most New
Zealanders about the
Joneses and it's
likely they'll wax
lyrical about Ian
and Michael; the
towering lock and
bone-crunching
loosie.

`We are strong in
our loosies but we
are still short of
locks and props,
particularly at
loosehead,' he said.
Nevertheless, there
did emerge ..
several players of
distinct promise.

`The play of our
loosies was a
decisive factor,'
Coulter said ...

'LEICESTER RUTLEDGE
.. and I wouldn't be
happy about it,'
said the livewire
loosie .. `And the
game against France
for Southland was a
difficult game for a
loose forward to get
into.'

Though not lacking
fighting spirit, the
Otago team was
continually
unsettled by .. the
fiery loosies
[Waikato forwards]
...

Mark Treweek, Pony's
loosie, moved into
the front row but
they lost a number
of tight heads to
Pakuranga.

WGTON MAORI LOOSIES
HIT TOP GEAR

The 28-year-old
loosie is contracted
to the union until
the end of next
year.

Wellington was not
done, though,
especially not its
loosies, who played
themselves to a
standstill.

.. loosies Sam
Broomhall, Richie
McCaw and Scott
Robertson powered
over for true team
tries ...

Finding a loosie
about 1.94m who
could jump in the
lineout would be a
good start.

It came from a
scrum. Zinny
[Brooke] came off
the back and took
out their loosies.

"Their loosies are
fast to the ball and
they steal a lot of
ball as well."

[caption]
Blockbusting loosie
Sione Lauaki is
relishing his chance
to start for the All
Blacks in tomorow
night's Tri-Nations
decider against the
Wallabies.

It's murder out
there as a loosie
whenthe other pack
gets on top.

Of course a loosie
gets picked up for
hands in the ruck.
It's what you do.

As for loot bags,
Darling simply
deplores the name.
"I call them 'thank
you for coming to my
party' bags."

A piece of cake
wrapped up in a
paper napkin no
longer cuts the
mustard as a
farewell gift; loot
bags, or party bags,
have now became an
essential part of
the party scene.

Author: SLATTER

Quote:
This he remembered
above all things,

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote: Proceeding just fair, but with their regularity that follows a shearer getting his back used to the arduous job, the advancement went on but with a different and a rougher cut than was usual. More frequently application of the loppies galloping down the board, to the ever increasing cry of `Tar'. The cut was becoming rougher and numbers spoilt good work, and slowly the gore of the classer, the shepherds, and certainly that of William Steuart, rose... Conferences would be held, a slight glistening on the fibre of the fleece, when sunlight decreed `wet sheep' and then the shearers would declare a break, whilst the `loppies', paid wet or fine, would be put on varying jobs to fill in the time until the Lords and Masters of the situation agreed to work. Ibid. 50 The bell rang, the whole procedure stopped, shearers trooped out, half shorn sheep were pushed back into the catching pens. Jimmy Greave the classer hurriedly whispered to William Steuart todesist, but loppies, rousies, and even young Jim, who was assisting to pen up, followed out from the side door to where the shoots from the stands gave the nearest exit, to the level space of the outside turf, that made eventually the [boxing] ring.

A New Zealand native that isn't widely recognised, but which I think should be, is the ribbon wood Plagianthus regius which can be found over much of the country, including Stewart Island and the Chathams... The common name, ribbonwood, was given by the early settlers because of the tree's inner, ribbon-like bark. These layers are very tough and were once used by Maoris for making rope and twine for fishing nets.

gangs of `lumpers'
hoisting in the huge
casks etc.

The Lumpers `went
out' in support of
the coal-heavers.

Author: GRACE
Quote:
When she landed, she
tottered up the
wharf in such a
manner as to cause
the `lumpers' to
imagine she was
drunken &
disreputable.

Author: BOWMAN
Quote:
The term `lumpers'
came to denote the
men who manhandled
the cargo [in
1870's-80s].

A lumper in the
employ of Messrs
Gannawayand
Thompson,
stevedores.. had
themisfortune to
have his leg
broken..
whileworking in No.
3 hold of the
Delphic.

The oaths of a
number of mere
lumperswere of no
avail.

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author: FORSTER
Quote: We got some other new fish, viz. a small Lumpfish [[ed. fn] Cyclopterus pinnulatus of Descr. Anim., p.30], a small Blenny, both caught under the rocks at low water mark; some Starfish, Coats of mail water spouts, Centipus, Muscles & Turbines, besides in the Evening a Lamprey ... [[ed. fn] Petromyzon cirratus of Descr. Anim. p.112] was caught. We described all this and drew a new Sole.[ed. fn] Pleuronectes scapha of Descr. Anim . p.130]

Author: PHILLIPPS
Quote: Trachelochismus pinnulatus (Forster). LUMP-FISH.
Trachelochismus pinnulatus (Forster). Lump-fish.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: Lumpfish Trachelochismus pinnulatus (Bloch and Schn.) (Syn. T. guttulatus Hutton, Crepidogaster simus Hutton, and Diplocrepis tumidus Griffin)
Notes: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: LUMP-FISH Trachelochismus pinnulatus (Bloch and Schneider)

Author: NATUSCH
Quote: [The cling fish's] relative Trachelochismus , the lump fish, has a rather more pointed snout and no incisors. The lump fish lives in slightly less exposed parts of [rocky coasts.]

Author: PAUL et al.
Quote:
[index to common
names 283-293]
lumpfish 743-54

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
There was [postal]
work [in the 1960s],
hard satisfying
work. Unloading
parcel bags, huge
cumbersome
containers nicknamed
pre-fabs, from a
three-door Z. There
was slots, there was
lumps, there was
packing fragies in
bottlos, there was
the tying down of
the north line for a
clearance, the
scissors, lead seals
and squeezers. The
sorters on call-back
flicking circulars
withprecision. The
volcanoes of letters
on the facing-up
table, the checker
chanting the reds
onto the lorry, the
checker calling the
overseas in, London
45 ... The queue of
men working at the
parcel depot or the
postal siding ...
Tieing down the
cargon. ... The
sorters' school at
the posties' pub
known colloquially
as Box 44 or the
B.B.C., the Back Bar
of the Cecil. The
cheerful abuse of
cobbers.

Author: PETER
Quote:
lunatic soup:
methylated spirits
to those who could
not afford the real
thing.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
Lunatic soup. Strong
drink: New Zealand:
C. 20. B., 1941,
`Lack of vigour or
colour could not ...
be a charge levelled
against such terms
for strong drink as
lunatic soup, Africa
speaks, plonk,
steam, red Ned, or
sheep wash,'. In
Australia it
specifically =
`cheap red wine'
(B., 1942).
Elsewhere (Michael
Harrison, Reported
Safe Arrival, 1943)
we find the variant
lunatic'sbroth.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
lunatic soup
alcoholic drink,
including meths
(methylated
spirits). NZA.

Lunches.- The
morning and
afternoon teas
brought to the shed
for the shearers are
always called ls.
(C.)

...there was the
time I wet my pants
in the lunch shed...

Mr Smith.. has not
returned calls
asking for an
interview the
following day about
Dunedin's renowned
"tartan mafia", of
which he is a
leading light...
Though it may sound
like it, the "tartan
mafia" is not a
derogatory term for
the city's
close-knit business
community, which on
occasions also uses
the term... Mr Marsh
is one of Dunedin's
richest men, an
acountant who
invested wisely in
car-dealing,
property and
manufacturing
companies. He says
there is no "formal
tartan mafia".

The signs have been there for years. They've been in underwear ads where pouting boys, lunchboxes packed, gaze out of the pages of women's glossies... My current copy of Vogue has similar ads for perfume, all nudity and smoulder, though none is as lovingly explicit as a recent ad which featured a male model with his whole lunchbox unpacked.

[Advt] Luncheon
Sausage Swan 10d.
lb.

"I suppose you do
not make German
sausagenow?" asked
the chairman... "We
call it'luncheon',
sir," was the reply.

I had sandwiches.
Mum used to buy that
luncheon sauasage
stuff. With
home-made pickle.

There are homemade
dresses, luncheon
sausage and chores,
and the pack
mentality of
multiple siblings
left to their own
devices.

Some bring home the
bacon but many bring
home only luncheon
sausage.

Janie recites the
facts about
fish,lists the
various flavours of
luncheon sausage,
while Tim, opens up
about the
complexities of love
and sex, boredom,
restlessness and his
future.

Author: CHRISTIE
Quote:
Vera also cooked the
meals, which
consisted
monotonously of
porridge for
breakfast, Belgium
(luncheon) sausage
with rice and curry
sauce ...

Author: SANSOM
Quote:
[Horse Shoe Bay] is
a good beach on
which to find the
big strong shells,
the ostrich-foot, a
big whelk, and the
southern volute, or
dog shell, the
lunella or catseye
shell, and the rare
modelia, also with a
catseye to close its
door.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
lungbuster
cigarette.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote: The old process of breaking-in horses is mentioned on Nov 5th, 1860, where a young horse was `lunged and mounted'. Ibid. 108 The diary mentions a `lunged horse'. This is never seen now. Mr. Kennard described the process as using a halter or `cavison' [cavesson], with a rein or rope, and running the horse round a circle until it was tired. This was for breaking in and training purposes, and was called `lunge-ing' Ibid.108 The diary mentions `lunged horse.' This is never seen now. Mr. Kennard described the process asusing a halter or `cavison,' [cavesson], with a rein or rope, and running the horse round a circle until it was tired. This was for breaking in and training purposes, and was called `lunge-ing.'

Author: BATHGATE
Quote:
They brought [the
colt] out to an open
piece of ground
where they `lunged'
[it] for some time.

Author: LELAND
Quote:
lux: (A) TO VACUUM
one's carpet (B) a
VACUUM CLEANER.
This, like hoover,
is a corruption of a
brand name. In this
case, Electrolux,
which appears to be
the most widely
usedvacuum cleaner
in New Zealand.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
Down the back the
lunkos [sc the
hoons, a crudely
behaved pair] were
playing a crooner
complaining to
listeners [141] that
somebody was
`breaking my heart
in two', a sentiment
Isuspected was
wasted on them.

I came unexpectedly
upon a savage
"lurcher" who had
bailed up
half-a-dozen sheep
in a cul-de-sac and
was systematically
worrying them to
death.

After recent battles
with Auckland street
lurgy who specialise
in larceny, I have
been slightly
dubious about
treading outdoors.

If he doesn't break
away from [the
conditions] Through
some underhanded
`lurk'.

Author: SARGE
Quote:
Lurk - (Army slang)
A scheme for dodging
work or duty.

lurk ... n. 3.
Austral. & N.Z. sl.
a scheme for
success.

Author: COOZE
Quote:
After years of hard
work/ He had learnt
all the lerk/ And
prayed hard for a
chance to get rich.

Author: HILLIARD
Quote:
Yet unless he got
into some `lurk'
like that he'd be a
casual labourer, a
wage-worker for the
rest of his days.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
lurk job, plan,
ruse, hiding place,
hangout (also
Brit.); a frequent
example: `You're on
to a good lurk',
meaning a cushy job;
c. 1916. NZA.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
Stamping was a good
lurk.

I'll raise my
Ebenezer. And I'll
have `down with all
the lush'.

Author: ANZAC
Quote:
...Whisky that takes
the lining of your
throat down with it.
... the kind of lush
that gives you a
sixty-horse dose of
the jim-jams while
you wait.

Source: Grif: a Story of Colonial Life
Author: FARJEON
Quote:
... he used to lush
- my eye! ... Well,
when he was pretty
well screwed, he
used to lay intous
...

His [the
gumdigger's] surplus
money may be banked,
though in nine cases
out of ten, it goes
in a `lush up'

...the present
Police custom, when
lushingtons have
money about 'em, to
bail 'em.

Author: FERGUSON
Quote:
Teddy was a
Lushington, Teddy
was a man/ Who ne'er
refused .../ To have
a round or stand a
shout .../

Author: CHAMIER
Quote:
The commodore had no
liking for his
wife's brother, whom
he denounced loudly
as a worthless
`lushington'.

Author: THATCHER
Quote:
(Sights at
Grahamstown) And
horses in the horrid
muck will often
settle down,/ And
lushy fellows lose
their boots in the
mud at Grahamstown./

[The Snares are]
almost entirely
covered with scrub
and trees of stunted
growth, the Tupari,
Akeake, and
Kokomuka. Of
M'Quarrie cabbage
there is abundance,
and of fine growth,
some of the leaves
measuring two feet
in diameter.Patches
clear of scrub are
clothed with Lutaki
tussock.

Author: PAUL et al.
Quote:
[index to common
names 283-293]
luvar, luvaru 2123

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: Luvar Luvarus imperialis . Rafinesque
Notes: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes

Author: PHILLIPPS
Quote: Luvarus imperialis . Rafinesque. LUVARU.

... I had no doubt
that he had secured
a specimen of the
rare Luvaru or
Silver King.

Author: HALL
Quote:
Refused to 'lux' the
venetians.

(A Male Au Pair) My
conditions were
spelt out - ... the
house must be
cleaned twice a
week, vacuumed,
mopped, dusted,
polished and jiffed,
the dishes washed
... - in two hours a
day. [134] I jiffed
the bath, handbasin
and loo, polished
the mirrors, ...
then luxed the
carpet.

lux to vacuum; short
for electrolux, used
to puzzling effect
on English
immigrants in Roger
Hall play Prisoners
of Mother England;
lux the Venetians
vacuum clean the
Venetian blinds.

Shifting from the
South Island to
theNorth - from
Invercargill all the
way upto
Morrinsville...
Things that stick
outmost is we roll
our R's, we
call'luncheon'
'belgium' and we
call
'vacuumcleaning'
'luxing'.

Author: MACKIE
Quote:
We were glad now and
then to throw
ourselves under a
Manuka bush and
partake of some
bread and cheese
provided us by our
friends. I saw a
small bittern and
gathered an
excellent Lycopodium
half trailing half
climbing plant.

Source: In the Land of the Tui
Author: WILSON
Quote:
Trails of lycopodium
and red berries
decorated a table
covered with ...
food fit for the
gods.

(And) Lycopodium
volubile giant
lycopodium.

Author: MANDER
Quote:
The stunted manuka
was brown, the
crawling lycopodium
was brown, the very
fern had a rusted
look.

Author: HOWE
Quote:
[Lyc. fer]
Pohutukawa ... and
lycopodium fern made
an enchanting
display on the
adjoining hills and
added to the
splendour of our
Christmas
decorations.

Author: DEMPSEY
Quote:
Linking the
mingi-mingi and the
tree trunks, the
curling trails of a
lycopodium made a
vignette of delicate
beauty.

Author: SANSOM
Quote:
lycopodium, a
beautiful [143] wiry
green ground-creeper
is lush; the now
rare native brown
duck is still to be
seen ...

Author: DOMETT
Quote: Of fragrant broom and ferny plume/ And winding woven lycopod/ Close-creping - ... Ibid 2/337 Lycopodium volubile, or L. densum.

Caseous
lymphadenitis is
referred to as
`C.L.A.' or `lympho'
in the works killing
sheets. ... There is
substantial economic
loss ... as

Author: NEAVE
Quote:
[Colin Hercus's]
achievements ... in
such matters as
feeding sheep on
oats in the winter,
the control of
lympho, the use of
sulphur in top
dressing, ... the
battle against white
muscle disease with
delenium - these ...
are part of New
Zealand's
Agricultural
History.

Ginette McDonald's
Lyn of Tawa act - an
urban female Fred
Dagg take on the
township - mortified
him. He could only
cringe when Lyn's
Royal Variety
Concert performance
included an
invitation to the
Duke of Edinburgh to
open Tawa's new
piddling pool.

The voice was
speaking pure New
Zild of a type
rarely encountered,
in a flow of mangled
vowels and
consonants that made
Lyn of Tawa sound
like an Oxbridge
graduate by
comparison.

I think Lynn of
Tawa's monologues
play to two
different audiences.
The natives laugh at
the feeble jokes but
see nothing unusual
about the accent in
which these are
delivered; we
migrants don't think
much of the jokes
but keenly
appreciate Miss
McDonald's brilliant
mimicry of country
Kiwi dialect.

And talking like
that Lyn of Tawa on
the tv.
